titleStmt.title: The Roundheads, or, The good old cause a comedy as it is acted at His Royal Highness the Dukes Theatre / by Mrs. A. Behn.
titleStmt.author: Behn, Aphra, 1640-1689.
Tatham, John, fl. 1632-1664. Rump.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for D. Brown ... and H. Rhodes ...,

notesStmt.note: "Great part, both of the plot and language of this play, is borrowed from Tatham's comedy called, The Rump"-- Baker, D.E. Biog. dram.
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

div.p: THE ROUNDHEADS OR, The Good Old Cause, A COMEDY As it is Acted at His Royal Highness the DUKES Theatre. By Mrs. A. Behn.

LONDON, Printed for D. Brown at the Black Swan and Bible without Temple bar▪ and Benskin in St. Brides Church Yard, and H. Rhodes next door to the Bear Tavern neer Bride Lane in Fleetstreet. MDCLXXXII.

div.head: To the Right Noble Henry Fitz-Roy, Duke of Grafton, Earle of Sutton, Viscount of Ipswich, Baron of Sudbury, Knight of the most Noble Order of the Garter, and Colonell of his Majesties Regiment of Foot Guards, &c.
div.p: DEdications which were Originally design'd, as a Tribute to that Reverence and just esteem we ought to pay the Great and Good; are now so corrupted with Flattery, that they rarely either find a Reception in the World, or merit that Patronage they wou'd implore. But I without fear Aproch the great Object being above that mean and mercenary Art; nor can I draw the Lovely Picture half so charming and so manly as it is; and that Author may more properly boast of a Lucky Hint, whose choice and fortune is so good, then if he had pleas'd all the different ill Iudging world besides in the business of the Play: for none that way, can ever hope to please all; in an Age when Faction rages, and differing Parties disagree in all things— But coming the first day to a new Play with a Loyal Title, and then even the sober and tender conscienc'd, throng as to a forbidden Conventicle: fearing the Cub of their old Bear of Reformation should be expos'd, to the scorn of the wicked, and dreading (tho but the faint shadow of their own deformity) their Rebellion, Murders, Massacres and Villanies, from 40 upwards, should be Represented for the better undeceiving and informing of the World, flock in a full Assembly with a pious design to Hisse and Rail it as much out of countenance as they would Monarchy, Religion, Laws, and Honesty; throwing the Act of Oblivion in our Teeths, as if that (whose mercy can not make them forget their Old Rebellion) cou'd hinder honest truths from breaking out upon 'em in Edifying Plays, where the Loyal hands ever out-do their venom'd Hisse; a good and happy omen, if Poets maybe allowd for Prophets as of old they were: and tis as easily seen at a new Play how the Royal Interest thrives, as at a City Election, how the good Old Cause is carried on; as a Noble Peer lately said, Tho' the Tories have got the better of us at the Play, we carried it in the City by many Voyces, God be praysed!

This Play, call'd, The Roundheads, which I humbly lay at your Graces feet, Pardon the Title, and Heaven defend you from the bloody Race, was carryed in the
House nemine contra dicente, by the Royal Party, and under your Graces Ilustrious Patronage is safe from any new Seditious affronts abroad; Your Grace alone whom Heaven and Nature has form'd the most adorable Person in the whole Creation, with all the advantages of a Glorious birth, has a double right and power to defend all that aproch you for sanctuary; your very Beauty is a guard to all you daigne to make safe: for You were born for Conquest every way? even what Phanatick, what peevish Politition, testy with Age, Diseases, miscarried Plots, disappointed Revolutions, envious of Power, of Princes, and of Monarchy, and mad with Zeal for Change and Reformation, could yet be so far lost to sence of Pleasure, as not to turn a Rebel to Revenge, the Good old Cause, and the patronage to Plebean sedition with only looking on you, 'twoud force his meger face to blushing smiles, and make him swear he had mistook the side, curse his own Party, and if possible, be reconcild to Honesty again: such power have charms like Yours to calm the soul, and will in spight of You plead for me to the disaffected, even when they are at Wars with Your Birth and power. But this Play for which I humbly beg Your Graces Protection, needs it in a more peculiar manner, it having drawn down Legions upon its head, for its Loyalty— what, to Name us cryes one, tis most abominable, unheard of daring cryes another— she deserves to be swing'd cryes a third; as if twere all a Libel, a scandal impossible to be provd, or that their Rogueries were of so old a Date their Reign were past remembrance or History; when they take such zealous care to renew it daily to our memories: And I am satisfied, that they that will justifie the best of these Traytors, deserves the fate of the worst, and most manifestly declare to the World by it, they wou'd be at the Old Game their fore-Fathers played with so good success, yet if there be any honest loyal man alied to any here nam'd, I heartily beg his Pardon for any offensive Truth I have spoken, and 'tis a wonderful thing that amongst so Numerous a Flock they will not allow of one mangy Sheep; not one Rogue in the whole Generation of the Association. Ignoramus the 1st and the 2d.

But as they are, I leave e'm to your Grace to Iudge of e'm; to whom I humbly present this small Mirror, of the late wretched Times: wherein your Grace may see something of the Miseries three the Most Glorious Kingdoms of the Vniverse were reduc't to; where your Royal Ancestors victoriously Reign'd for so many hundred years: How they were Govern'd, Parcell'd out, and deplorable inslav'd, and to what Low, Prostituted Lewdness they fell at last: where the Nobility and Gentry were the most contemn'd and despis'd part of them, and such Meane, (and till then obscure) Villains Rul'd, and Tyraniz'd, that no Age, nor Time, or scarce a Parish Book makes mention or cou'd show there was any such Name or Family. Yet these were those that impudently Tug'd for Empire, and Prophan'd that Illustrious Throne and Court, so due then, and possest now (through the infinite Mercies of God to this bleeding Nation) by the best of Monarchs; a Monarch, who had yet the divine goodness to Pardon even his worst of Enemies what was past; Nay, out of his Vast and God-like Clemency, did more than Heaven it self can do, put it out of his Power by an Act of Oblivion, to punish the unparalell'd Injuries done His Sacred Person, and the rest of the Royal Family: How great his Patience has been since, I leave to all the World to judge: but
Heaven be prais'd, he has not yet forgot the Sufferings and Murders of the Glorious Martyr of ever blessed memory, Your Graces Sacred Grandfather, and by what Arts and Ways that Devilish Plot was layed! and will like a skilful Pilate, by the wreck of one Rich Vessell, learn how to shun the danger of this present. Threatning and saved the rest from sinking; The Clouds already begin to disappear, and the face of things to change, thanks to Heaven His Majesties infinite Wisdom, and the Over-Zeal of the (falsly called) True Protestant Party: Now we may pray for the King and his Royal Brother, defend his Cause, and assert his Right, without the fear of a taste of the Old Sequestration call'd a Fine; Guard the Illustrious Paire, good Heaven, from Hellish Plots, and all the Devilish matchinations of Factious Cruelties: and you, great Sir, (whose Merits have so justly deserv'd that glorious Command so lately trusted to your Care, which Heaven increase, and make your glad Regiment Armyes for our safety. May you become the great Example of Loyalty and Obedience, and stand a firm and unmoveable Pillar to Monarchy, a Noble Bull-work to Majesty; defend the Sacred Cause, imploy all that Youth, Courage, and Noble Conduct which God and Nature purposely has endued you with, to serve the Royal Intrest: You, Sir, who are obliged by a double Duty to Love, Honour, and Obey his Majesty, both as a Father and a King! O undissolvable Knot! O Sacred Vnion! what Duty, what Love, what Adoration can express or repay the Debt we owe the first, or the Alegiance due to the last, but where both meet in one, to make the Tye Eternal; Oh what Counsel, what Love of Power, what fancied Dreams of Empire, what fickle Popularity can inspire the heart of man, or any Noble mind, with Sacreligious thoughts against it, can harbour or conceive a stubborn disobedience: Oh what Son can desert the Cause of an Indulgent Parents, what Subject, of such a Prince, without renouncing the Glory of his Birth, his Loyalty, and good Nature.

Ah Royal lovely Youth! beware of false Ambition; wisely believe your Elevated Glory, (at least) more happy then a Kings, you share their Ioys, their pleasures and magnificence, without the toiles and business of a Monarch, their carefull dayes and restless thoughtful nights; know, you are blest with all that Heaven can give, or you can wish; your Mind and Person such, so excellent, that Love knows no fault it would wish to mend, nor Envy to increase! blest with a Princess of such undisputable charming Beauty, as if Heaven designing to take a peculiar care in all that concerns your happiness, had form'd her on purpose, to compleat it.

Haile happy glorious Paire! the perfect joy and pleasure of all that look on ye, for whom all Tongues and Hearts have Prayers and Blessings; May you out-live Sedition, and see your Princely Race as Numerous as Beautifull, and those all great and Loyal Supporters of a long Race of Monarchs of this Sacred Line. This shall be the perpetuall wish, this the Eternal Prayer of

closer.signed: Your Graces most Humble, and most Obedient Servant, A. Behn.

div.head: PROLOGUE, Spoken by the Ghost of Huson ascending from Hell drest as a Cobler.
div.l: I Am the Ghost of him who was a true Son
Of the late GOOD OLD CAVSE, Ecliped, Huson,
Rous'd by strange scandal, from th' eternal flame
With noise of Plotts, of wonderous birth and name
Whilst the sly Jesuit robs us of our fame.
Can all their Conclave, tho' with Hell th' agree
Act mischief equal to Presbittery?
Look back on our success in Forty One,
Was ever braver Villanies carryed on
Or new ones now more hopefully begun.
And shall our unsuccess our merit lose
And make us quit the Glory of our Cause!
No, Hire new Villains, Rogues without remorse
And let no Law nor Conscience stop your course.
Let Polititions order the Confusion
And let the Saints pay Pious Contribution.
Pay those that Rail, and those that can delude
With scribling Nonsence the Loose Multitude.
Pay well your Witnesses, they may not run
To the right side and tell who set 'em on
Pay 'em so well, that they may ne'r Recant
And so turn Honest meerly out of want.
Pay Juries that no formal Laws may harm us
Let Treason be secur'd by Ignoramus.
Pay Bully Whig, who Loyal writers bang
And honest Tories in Effigie hang:
Pay those that burn the Pope to please the fools
And dayly pay Right Honourable Tooles
Pay all the Pulpit knaves that Treason brew
And let the zealous Sisters pay 'em too;
Justices, bound by Oath, and obligation
Pay them the utmost price of their Damnation
Not to disturb our useful Congregation.
Nor let the Learned Rabble be forgot
Those Pious hands that crown our hopeful Plott.
No, Modern States-men cry tis Lunacy
To barter Treason with such Rogues as we.
But subtiller Oliver did not disdain
His Mightier Politiques with ours to joyn.
I, for all uses in a State was able
Cou'd Mutiny, cou'd fight, hold forth, and Cobble.
Your lazy State man, may sometimes direct
But your small busie knaves the Treason Act.

body.head: THE ROVND-HEADS, OR THE Good Old Cause.

div.head: Scene I. The Street.
div.stage: Enter three Souldiers, and Corporal Right.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: AH Rogues, the World runs finely round, the bus'ness is done.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Done, the Town's our own, my fine Rascal.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: We'll have Harlots by the Belly, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Those are Commodities I confess I wou'd fain be truckling for,— but no words of that Boy.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stand, who go's there? To them a Ioyner and Felt-maker.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Who are you for,— hah?

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: Are for Friend; we are for Gad and the Lord Fleetwood.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Fleetwood, knock 'em down, Fleetwood that snivelling Thief?

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Why Friends, who are ye for?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: For? who shou'd we be for, but Lambert, Noble Lambert? Is this a time o'th' day to declare for Fleetwood, with a Pox? indeed. i'th morning 'twas a Question had like to have been decided with push a Pike.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Dry blows wou'd ne'r a don't, some must have sweat blood for't, but— 'tis now decided.

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: Decided!

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Yes, decided Sir, without your Rule for't.

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: Decided? by whom Sir? by us the Free-born Subjects of England, by the Honourable Committee of Safety, or the Right Reverend City? without which Sir, I humbly conceive, your Declaration for Lambert is illegal, and against the Property of the People.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Plain Lambert; here's a sawcy Dog of a Joyner; Sirrah, get ye home, and mind your Trade, and save the Hang-man a labour.

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: Look ye, Friend, I fear no Hang-man in Christendom; for Conscience and Publick good, for Liberty and Property, I dare as far as any man.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Liberty and Property, with a pox, in the mouth of a Joyner; you are a pretty Fellow to settle the Nation,— what says my Neighbour Felt-maker?

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Why verily, I have a high respect for my honourable Lord Fleetwood, he is my intimate Friend, and till I find his Party the weaker, I hope my Zeal will be strengthened for him.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Zeal for Fleetwood, Zeal for a Halter, and that's your due: Why, what has he ever done for you? Can he lead you out to Battel? Can he silence the very Cannon with his Eloquence alone?— Can he talk— or fight— or—

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: But verily he can pay those that can, and that's as good— and he can pray—

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Let him pray, and we'll fight, and see whose bus'ness is done first; We are for the General, who carries charms in every syllable; can act both the Souldier and the Courtier, at once expose his Breast to dangers for our sakes— and tell the rest of the pretending Slaves a fair Tale, but hang 'em sooner than trust 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.p: Ay, ay, a Lambert, a Lambert, he has courage, Fleetwood's an Ass to him.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Hum— here's Reason Neighbour. to the Ioyner.

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: That's all one, we do not act by reason.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Fleetwood's a Coward.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: A Blockhead.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: A snivelling Fool; a General in the Hangings, no better.

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: What think ye then of Vane?

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: As of a Fool, that has dreamt of a new Religion, and only fit to reign in that Fifth Monarchy he preaches so much up; but no King in this Age.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: What of Haslerig?

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: A Hangman for Haslerig, I cry, No, no, One and all, a Lambert, a Lambert; he is our General, our Protector, our King▪ our Keiser, our— even what he pleases himself.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Well, if he pleases himself he pleases me.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: He's our Rising Sun, and we'll adore him, for the Speaker's Glory's set,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: At nought, Boyes; how the Rogue look'd when his Coach was stop'd?

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: Under favour, what said the Speaker?

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: What said he? prethee what cou'd he say that we wou'd admit for Reason? Reason and our bus'ness are two things: Our Will was Reason and Law too, and the Word of Command lodg'd in our Hilts: Cobbet and Duckenfield show'd 'em Cock-pit Law.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He understood not Souldiers Dialect; the Language of the Sword puzled his Understanding; the Keeneness of which, was too sharp for his Wit, and over-rul'd his Roles— therefore he very mannerly kiss'd his hand, and wheel'd about,—

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: To the place from whence he came,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And e're long, to the Place of Execution.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: No, damn him, he'll have his Clergy.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Why is he such an Infidel to love the Clergy?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: For his Ends: But come, lets go drink the General's Health; Lambert! not Fleetwood, that Son of a Custard, always quaking.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, Lambert I say,— besides, he's a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Come, Come, Brother Souldier, let me tell you, I fear you have a Stewart in your Belly.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am sure you have a Rogue in your Heart, Sirrah, which a Man may perceive through that sanctify'd Dogs Face of yours; and so get ye gone ye Rascals, and delude the Rabble with your canting Politicks. Everyone beats 'em.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Nay, and you be in Wrath, I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No matter Sir, I'll make you know I'm a Free-born Subject, there's Law for the Righteous Sir, there's Law. Go out.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: There's Halters ye Rogues?—

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Come Lads, let's to the Tavern, and drink Success to change; I doubt not but to see 'em chop about, till it come to our great Heroe again.— Come, to the Tavern.

div.stage: Going out, are met by Loveless and Freeman who enter, and stay the Corporal.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'll follow ye Comrade presently. Ex. the rest of the Souldiers,— Save ye noble Collonel.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How is't Corporal?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A brave World Sir, full of Religion, Knavery, and Change; we shall shortly see better days.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I doubt it Corporal;

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'le warrant you Sir,— but have you had never a Billet, no Present, nor Love-remembrance to day, from my good Lady Desbro?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: None, and wonder at it: Hast thou not seen her Page to day?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Faith Sir I was imploy'd in Affairs of State, by our Protector that shall be, and could not call.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Protector that shall be? who's that, Lambert or Fleetwood, or both?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I care not which, so it be a Change; but I mean the General?— but Sir, my Lady Desbro is now at Morning Lecture here hard by, with the Lady Lambert.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Seeking the Lord for some great Mischief or other.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: We have been there, but could get no Opportunity of speaking to her,— Loveless, know this Fellow,— he's honest and true to the Heroe, though a Red-Coat? I trust him with my Love, and have done with my Life.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Love! Thou can'st never make me believe thou art earnestly in Love with any one of that damn'd Reformation.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Thou art a Fool; where I find Youth and Beauty, I adore, let the Saint be true or false.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
'Tis a Scandal to one of us to converse with 'em; they are all sanctify'd Iilts; and there can be neither Credit nor Pleasure in keeping 'em Company;
and 'twere enough to get the Scandal of an Adherer to their devilish Politicks to be seen with 'em.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What, their Wives?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, their Wives. What see'st thou in 'em but Hypocrisie? Make Love to 'em, they answer you in Scripture.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, and lye with you in Scripture too. Of all Whores, give me your zealous Whore; I never heard a Woman talk much of Heaven, but she was much for the Creature too. What do'st think I had thee to the Meeting for?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To hear a Rascal hold forth for Bodkins and Thimbles, Contribution my beloved! to carry on the Good Cause, that is, Roguery, Rebellion, and Treason, prophaning the sacred Majesty of Heaven, and our glorious Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But— were there not pretty Women there?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Damn 'em for sighing, groaning Hypocrites.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But there was one, whom, that handsom Face and Shape of yours, gave more occasion for sighing, than any Mortification caus'd by the Cant of the Lay-Elder in the half Hogs Head; Did'st thou not mind her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not I, damn it I was all Rage, and had'st not thou restrain'd me, I had certainly pull'd that Rogue of a Holder-forth by the Ears from his sanctify'd Tub. 'Sdeath he hum'd and haw'd all my Patience away, nose'd and snivel'd me to Madness. Heaven! That thou should'st suffer such Vermin to infect the Earth, such Wolves amongst thy Flocks, such Thieves and Robbers of all Laws of God and Man, in thy holy Temples. I rave to think to what thou'rt fall'n, poor England!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But the she Saint—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No more, were she as fair as Fancy could imagine, to see her there,— wou'd make me loath the Form; she that can listen to the dull Non-sence, the bantering of such a Rogue, such an illiterate Rascal, must be a Fool, past sense of loving, Free-man.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Thou art mistaken.— But, did'st thou mind her next the Pulpit?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Plague upon the whole Congregation: I minded nothing but how to fight the Lord's Battel with that damn'd sham Parson; whom I had a mind to beat.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: My Lady Desbro is not of that Persuasion, but an errant Heroick in her Heart, and feigns it only to have the better occasion to serve the Royal Party. I knew her, and lov'd her before she married.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She may chance then to be sav'd.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come, I'll have thee bear up briskly to some one of 'em, it may redeem thy Sequestration; which, now thou see'st no hopes of compounding, puts thee out of Patience.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let 'em take it, and the Devil do 'em Good with it: I scorn it should be said I have a Foot of Land in this ungrateful and accursed Island; I'd rather beg where Laws are obey'd and Justice perform'd, than be powerful where Rogues and base born Rascals rule the Rost.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But suppose now, dear Loveless, that one of the Wives of these Pageant Lords should fall in love with thee, and get thy Estate again, or pay thee double for't?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I wou'd refuse it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And this for a little dissembled Love, a little Drudgery—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not a night by Heav'n— not an hour— no not a single kiss, I'd rather make love to an Incubus.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But suppose 'twere the new Protectoress her self, the fine Lady Lambert?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The greatest Devil of all; Damn her, dost think I'll Cuckold the Ghost of old Oliver?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The better; there's some Revenge in't; do'st know her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Never saw her, nor care to do.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Collonel, Do you command me any thing?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes, I'll send thee with a Note— Let's step into a Shop and write it; Loveless stay a moment, and I'll be with thee. Ex. Free and Corporal.

div.stage: Enter L. Lambert, L. Desbro, Gilliflowr, Pages with great Bibles, and Footmen: Love. walks sullenly, not seeing 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: O, I'm impatient to know his Name; ah, Desbro, he betray'd all my Devotion; and when I wou'd have pray'd, Heav'n knows, it was to him, and for him onely.

sp.speaker: L. Des.
sp.p: What manner of man was it?

sp.speaker: L. Lam.
sp.l: I want words to describe him; not tall, nor short; well made, and such a face— Love, Wit, and Beauty revel'd in his Eyes:
From whence he shot a thousand winged Darts
That pierc'd quite through my Soul.

sp.speaker: L. Des.
sp.l: Seem'd he a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: L. Lam.
sp.p: A God! Altho his out-side were but mean; but he shone th'ro like Lightning from a Cloud, and shot more piercing Rayes.

sp.speaker: L. Des.
sp.p: Stay'd he long?

sp.speaker: L. Lam.
sp.l: No; methought he grew displeas'd with our Devotion
And seem'd to contradict the Parson with his Angry Eyes.
A Friend he had too with him, young and handsom,
Who seeing some disorder in his Actions, got him away.
— I had almost forgot all Decency,
And started up to call him, but my Quality
And wanting something to excuse that Fondness,
Made me decline with very much adoe.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Heav'ns, Madam, I'll warrant they were Heroicks.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Heroicks!

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Cavaliers, Madam, of the Royal Party.

sp.speaker: L. D.
sp.l: They were so, I knew one of 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Ah Desbro, do'st thou?
Ah Heav'ns, that they should prove Heroicks!

sp.speaker: L. D.
sp.p: You might have known that by the Conquest; I never heard, e're one o'th t'other Party ever gain'd a Heart: and indeed, Madam, 'tis a just Revenge, our Husbands make Slaves of them, and they kill all their Wives. Love. sees 'em, and starts.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hah, what have we here?— Women— faith, and handsom too— I never saw a Form more Excellent! whoe're they are, they seem of Quality,— by Heav'n, I cannot take my Eyes from her. pointing to La. Lam.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Hah, he's yonder, my Heart begins to fail,
My trembling Limbs refusing to support me—
His Eyes seem fix'd on mine too; ah, I faint— leans on Desbro.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: My Ladies Coach, William— quickly, she faints.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Madam, can an unfortunate Stranger's aid add any thing to the recovery of so much Beauty? bowing, and holding her.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Ah, Wou'd he knew how much! aside.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Support her, Sir, till her Ladiships Coach comes— I beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Not Atlas bore up Heaven with greater Pride.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: — I beg your Pardon, Sir, for this Disorder
That has occasion'd you so great a Trouble—
You seem a Gentleman— and consequently
May need some Service done you; name the way,
I shall be glad to let you see my Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If there be ought in me, that merits this amazing Favour from you, I owe my thanks to Nature that indow'd me with something in my Face that spoke my Heart.

sp.speaker: La. Lam▪
sp.p: Heav'n! how he looks and speaks— to Desbro, aside.

sp.speaker: L. Des.
sp.p: Oh, these Heroicks, Madam, have the most charming Tongues.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Pray come to me— and ask for any of my Officers, and you shall have admittance—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Who shall I ask for Madam? for I'm yet ignorant to whom I owe for this great Bounty.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Not know me! Thou art indeed a Stranger. I thought I'd been so Elevated above the common Crowd, it had been visible to all Eyes who I was.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Pardon my Ignorance;
My Soul conceives ye all that Heaven can make ye,
Of Great, of Fair and Excellent;
But cannot guess a Name to call you by
But such as wou'd displease ye—
— My heart begins to fail, and by her Vanity
I fear she's one of the new Race of Quality: aside.
— But be she Devil, I must love that Form.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Hard Fate of Greatness, We so highly Elevated
Are more expos'd to Censure than the little ones,
By being forc'd to speak our Passions first.
— Is my Coach ready?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: It waits your Honour.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: I give you leave to visit me— ask for the General's Lady, if my Title be not by that Time alter'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Pistols and Daggers to my Heart— 'tis so.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Adiew Sir. Ex. all but Lov. who stands musing.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter with thee?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Prethee wake me Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Wake thee!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I dream! by Heav'n I dream!
Nay yet the lovely Phantam's in my View,
Oh! wake me, or I sleep to perfect Madness.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: What ayl'st thou, what did'st dream of?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: A strange fantastick Charmer,
A thing just like a Woman friend,
It walk't and look'd with wonderous Majesty,
Had Eyes that kill'd, and Graces deck'd her Face;
But when she talk'd, mad as the Winds she grew.
Chimera in the form of Angel, Woman!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Who the Devil meanest thou?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: By Heav'n I know not; but, as she vanish'd hence, she bad me come to th' General's!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why this is she I told thee ey'd thee so at the Conventicle; 'tis Lambert, the renown'd, the famous Lady Lambert— Mad call'st thou her? 'tis her ill acted Greatness, thou mistak'st; thou art not us'd to the Pageantry of these Women yet; they all run thus mad: 'tis greatness in 'em, Loveless.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And is thine thus, thy Lady Desbro?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: She's of another Cut, she marryed as most do, for Interest,— but what— thou't to her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: If Lightening stop my way,
Perhaps a sober view may make me hate her. Exit. both.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: My Lord, now is your time, you may be King; Fortune is yours, you've time it self by th' fore-lock.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: If I thought so, I'd hold him fast by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: If you let slip this Opportunity, my Lord, you are undone— Aunt Caesar, aut Nullus.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: But Fleetwood—

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Hang him soft head.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: True, he's of an easie Nature, yet if thou did'st but know how little Wit governs this mighty Universe, thou wou'dst not wonder men should set up him.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: That will not recommend him at this Iuncto, though he's an excellent Tool for your Lordship to make use of; and therefore, use him Sir as Cataline did Lentulus; drill the dull Fool with hopes of Empire, on, and that all tends to his Advancement only: The Block-head will believe the Crown his own: what other Hopes could make him ruine Richard, a Gentleman of Qualities a thousand times beyond him?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: They were both too soft; an ill Commendation for a General, who should be rough as storms of War it self.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: His Time was short, and yours is coming on; Old Oliver had his.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I hate the Memory of that Tyrant Oliver.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: So do I, now he's dead, and serves my Ends no more. I lov'd the Father of the Great Heroick, whilst he had Power to do me good: he failing, Reason directed me to the Party then prevailing, the Fag End of the Parliament: 'tis true, I took the Oath of Allegiance, as Oliver, your Lordship, Tony, and the rest did, without which, we could not have sat in that Parliament; but that Oath was not for our Advantage, and so better broke than kept.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I am of your Opinion my Lord.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Let Honesty and Religion preach against it; but how cou'd I have serv'd the Commons by deserting the King? how have show'd my self loyal to your Interest, by fooling Fleetwood, in the deserting of Dick; by dissolving the honest Parliament, and bringing in the odious Rump? how cou'd I have flatter'd Ireton, by telling him, Providence brought things about, when 'twas mere knavery all, and that the hand of the Lord was in't, when I knew the Devil was in't? or indeed, how cou'd I now advise you to be King, if I had started of Oaths, or prefer'd Honesty or Divinity before Interest and the Good Old Cause.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis most certain, he that will live in this World, must be indu'd with the three rare Qualities of Dissimulation, Equivocation, and mental Reservation.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: In which Excellency, Heav'n be prais'd, we out-do the Iesuits.

sp.speaker: L. Lamb.
sp.p: I'm glad to see you so well employ'd my Lord, as in Discourse with my Lord Whitlock he's of our party, and has Wit..

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Your Honour graces me too much.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lady is an absolute States-Woman.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Yes, I think things had not arriv'd to this exalted height, nor had you been in Prospect of a Crown, had not my Politicks exceeded your meaner Ambition.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I confess, I owe all my good fortune to thee.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord Wariston, Lord Hewson, Collonel Cobbet, and Collonel Duckenfield desire the Honour of waiting on you.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: This has a Face of Greatness— let 'em wait a while i'th' Antichamber.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Love, I wou'd have 'em come in.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: You wou'd have 'em, you wou'd have a Fools Head of your own; pray let me be Judge of what their Duty is, and what your Glory; I say I'll have 'em wait.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My Lord Fleetwood too is just alighted, shall he wait too Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: He may approach; and d' ye hear— put on your fawning looks, flatter him, and profess much Friendship to him, you may betray him with the more facility.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Madam, you counsel well, Ex. Page, re-enter with L. Fleetwood.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: My good Lord, your most submissive Servant.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: My Gracious Lord, I am your Creature— your Slave—

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: I profess ingeniously, I am much ingag'd to you, my good Lords; I hope things are now in the Lard's handling, and will go on well for his Glory and my Interest, and that all my good People of England will do things that become good Christians.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Doubt us not, my good Lord; the Government cannot be put into abler hands, than those of your Lordship; it has hitherto been in the hard clutches of Iews, Infidels, and Pagans.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Yea verily, Abomination has been in the hands of Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: But, my Lord, those hands, by my good Conduct, are now cut off, and our Ambition is, your Lordship wou'd take the Government upon you.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: I profess, my Lord, by ye and nay, I am asham'd of this Goodness, in making me the Instrument of saving Grace to this Nation; 'tis the great Work of the Lard.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: The Lard, Sir, I'll assure you the Lard has the least hand in your good fortune; I think you ought to ascribe it to the Cunning and Conduct of my Lord here, who so timely abandon'd the Interest of Richard.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Ingeniously, I must own, your good Lord can do much, and has done much; but 'tis our Method to ascribe all to the Powers above.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Then I must tell you, your Method's an ungrateful Method.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Peace, my Love.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Madam, This is the Cant we must delude the Rabble with.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Then let him use it there, my Lord, not amongst us, who so well understand one another.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Good Dear, be pacifi'd— and tell me, shall the Gentlemen without have admittance?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: They may. Page goes out.

div.stage: Enter Hewson, Desbro, Duckenfield, Wariston, and Cobbet.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Guds Benizon light on yu, my gued Loords, for this days work; Madam, I kiss your white Honds.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: My Lord, I have not been behind hand in this days turn of State.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: 'Tis confess'd, Sir; What wou'd you infer from that?

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Why, I wou'd know how things go; who shall be General, who Protector, or who King next.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: My Friend has well translated his meaning.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Fy, how that filthy Cobler Lord betrayes his Function.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: We're in a Chaos, a Confusion, as we are.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Indeed the Commonwealth at present is out at heels, and wants underlaying.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: And the People expect something suddenly from us.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: My Lords and Gentlemen, we must consider a while.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Bread a gued there's mickle Wisdom i that Sirs.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: It ought to be consulted betimes, my Lord, 'tis a matter of moment, and ought to be consulted by the whole Committee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: We design no other, my Lord, for which reason, at three a clock we'll meet at Wallingford House.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, do but settle the Affair, let's but know who's our Head, and 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Hew.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, no matter who; I hope 'twill be Fleetwood, for I have the length of his Foot already.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: You are the leading men, Gentlemen, your Voices will soon settle the Nation.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, we'll not fail at three a clock.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: This falls out well for me; for I have Bus'ness in Smithfield, where my Horses stand; and verily, now I think on't, the Rogue the Ostler has not given 'em Oates to day: Well, my Lords, farewel; if I come not time enough to Wallingford House, keep me a place in the Committee, and let my Voice stand for one, no matter who.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: A gued Mon I's warrant, and takes muckle Pains for the Gued o'th' Nation, and the Liberty o'th' Mobily:— The Diel confound 'em aud.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Come, my Lord Wariston, you are a wise man, What Government are you for?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Ene tol what ya please my gued Loord. takes him aside.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: What think you of a single Person here in my Lord Fleetwood?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Mary Sir, and he's a brave Mon, but gen I may cooncel, tak't for yar sel my gued Loord, ant be gued for him, 'tis ene gued for ya te.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: But above half the Nation are for him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Bread a gued, and I's for him than.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: The Will of the Lard be done; and since 'tis his Will, I cannot withstand my Fate— ingeniously.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: My Lord Wariston, a Word— what if Lambert were the Man? takes him aside.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Right Sir, Wons and ya have spoken aud; He's a brave Mon, a Mon indeed gen I's 'ave any Judgment.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: So I find this Property's for any use. aside.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord, I perceive Heaven and Earth conspire to make you our Prince.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Ingeniously, my Lords, the weight of three Kingdoms is a heavy Burden for so weak Parts as mine; therefore, I will, before I appear at Councel, go seek the Lard in this great Affair; and, if I receive a Revelation for it, I shall with all Humility espouse the Yoke, for the Good of his People and mine: and so Gad with us, the Commonwealth of England.

div.stage: Ex. Fleet. Desbro, Wariston, Duc. Cob. Hus. and Whit.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Poor deluded Wretch, 'tis not yet come to that.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: No my Dear, the Voice will go clearly for me; what with Bribes to some, Hypocrisie and Pretence of Religion to others, and promis'd Preferments to the rest, I have engag'd 'em all.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: And will you be a King?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You think that's so fine a thing— but let me tell you, my Love, a King's a Slave to a Protector, a King's ty'd up to a thousand Rules of musty Law, which we can break at Pleasure; we can rule without Parliaments, at least, chuse whom we please, make 'em agree to our Proposals, or set a Guard upon 'em, and starve 'em till they do.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: But their Votes are the strangest things,— that they must pass for Laws; you were never voted King.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: No, nor care to be: the sharpest Sword's my Vote, My Law, my Title. They voted Dick should reign, where is he now? They voted the great Heroicks from the Succession; but had they Arms or Men, as I have, you shou'd soon see what wou'd become of their Votes— No my Love! 'Tis this— must make me King. His Sword.
sp.l: Let Fleetwood and the Rump go seek the Lard,
My Empire and my Trust is in my Sword.

div.head: Scene I. A Chamber of State.
div.stage: Enter La. Lambert, Gilliflower, and Women-servants.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: GIlliflower, Has none been here to ask for any of my People, in order to his approach to me?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: None, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Madam! how dull thou art! wou't never learn to give me a better Title, than such an one as foolish Custom bestows on every common Wench?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Pardon my Ignorance, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Again Madam!

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Really, Madam, I shou'd be glad to know by what other Title you wou'd be distinguish'd?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Abominable dull! Do'st thou not know on what score my Dear is gone to Wallingford House?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: I cannot divine, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Heav'n help thy Ignorance! he's gone to be made Protector, fool, or at least, a King, thou Creature; And from this day I date my self her Highness.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: That will be very fine indeed, an't please your Highness.

sp.speaker: La Lam.
sp.p: I think 'twill sute better with my Person and Beauty than with that other Woman— what d' ye call her? Mrs. Cromwel— my shape— and Gat●— my Humour, and my Youth, have something more of Grandeur— have they not?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Infinitely, an't please you Highness.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Madam, a Man without has the boldness to ask for your Honour.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Honour, fool!

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Her Highness, Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Sawcily prest in, and struck the Porter for denying him entrance to your— Highness.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: What kind of Fellow was't?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: A rude, rough, Hectoring Swash, an't please your Highness; nay, and two or three times, Gad forgive me, he swore too.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: It must be he. aside.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: His Habit was something bad and Cavalierish— I believe 'tis some poor petitioning, begging Tory, who having been sequester'd, wou'd press your Highness for some Favour.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Yes, it must be he— ah foolish Creature! and can he hope Relief, and a villanous Cavalier? out upon 'em, poor Wretches— you may admit him tho', I long to hear how one of those things talk.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Oh most strangely, Madam,— an't please your Highness, I shou'd say.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: 'Tis he, I'll swear, Gilliflower, these Heroicks are punctual men,— how now, your Bus'ness with us, Fellow?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My bus'ness, Madam?—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Hast thou ever a Petition to us?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Petition, Madam?— Sure this put on Greatness is to amuse her Servants, or has she forgot that she invited me; or indeed forgot me?— aside.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Shall we search his Breeches, an't please your Highness, for Pistol, or other Instruments?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: No Boy, we fear him not, they say the Pow'rs above protect the Persons of Princes. walks away.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sure she's mad, yet she walks loose about,
And she has Charms even in her Raving Fit.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Answer me. What art thou? How shall I get my Servants hence with honour? aside.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: A Gentleman—
That cou'd have boasted Birth and Fortune too
Till these accursed Times, which Heav'n confound,
Racing out all Nobility, all Vertue,
Has render'd me the rubbish of the World;
Whilst new rais'd Rascals, Canters, Robbers, Rebells
Do Lord it o're the Free-born, Brave and Noble.

sp.speaker: La. La.
sp.p: You're very confident, know you to whom you speak? but I suppose you have lost your Estate, or some such trivial thing, which makes you angry.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, a trivial Estate of some five and twenty hundred pound a year, but I hope to see that Rogue of a Lord reduc'd to his Cobler's Stall again, or, more deserv'dly hang'd, that has it.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: I thought 'twas some such Grievance— but you must keep a good Tongue in your head, lest you be hang'd for Scandalum Magnatum— there's Law for ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No matter; then I shall be free from a damn'd Commonwealth, as you are pleas'd to call it, when indeed 'tis but a mungrel, mangy, Mock-Monarchy.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Is it your bus'ness Sir to rail?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You rais'd the Devil, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Madam, shall I call your Highness Guards, and secure the Traytor?

sp.speaker: La. La.
sp.l: No; that you may see how little I regard or fear him; leave us all— Ex. all but Gill.
We'll trust our Person in his hands alone—
— Now Sir— your Bus'ness? smilingly approaches him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam, I waited here by your Commands.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: How shall I tell him that I love him, Gilliflower?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Easily, Madam, tell him so in plain English. Madam, 'tis great; Women of your exalted height ever speak first; you have no Equals dare pretend to speak of love to you.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Thou art i'th' right— Do'st know my Quality, and thy own Poverty? And hast thou nothing to ask that I may grant?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sure she loves me! and I, frail flesh and blood,
Cannot resist her Charms; but she's of the damn'd Party. aside.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Are all your Party, Sir, so proud?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But what have I to do with Religion? Is Beauty the worse, or a kind Wench to be refus'd for Conventickling? She lives high on the Spoils of a glorious Kingdom, and why may not I live upon the Sins of the Spoiler? aside.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Sir— you are poor!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: So is my Prince; a Plague on the occasion.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: I think you are— no Fool too?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I wou'd I were, then I had been a Knave, had thriv'd, and possibly by this time had been tugging for rifled Crowns and Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: This Satyr ill befits my present Bus'ness with you,— you— want some Necessaries— as Cloaths, and Linnen too; and 'tis great pitty so proper a man shou'd want Necessaries. Gilliflower— take my Cabinet Key, and fetch the Purse of Broad-pieces that lyes in the lower Drawer; 'tis a small Present, Sir, but 'tis an Earnest of my farther Service, Gill. goes out, and returns with a Purse.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'm angry, that I find one Grain of Generosity in this whole Race of Hypocrites. aside.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Here Sir, 'tis only for your present use; for Cloaths— three hundred Pieces; let me see you sweet—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Stark mad, by this good day.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Ah Gilliflower! How prettily those Cavalier things charm; I wonder how the Powers above came to give them all the Wit, Softness, and Gallantry,— whilst all the great ones of our Age have the most slovenly, ungrateful, dull Behaviour; no Ayr, no Wit, no Love, or any thing to please a Lady with.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Truly Madam, there's a great Difference in the Men; yet Heav'n at first did it's part, but the Divel has since so over-done his, that what with the Vizor of Sanctity, which is the gadly Sneere, the drawing of the Face to a prodigious length, the formal language, with a certain Twang through the Nose, and the pious Gogle, they are fitter to scare Children than beget love in Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You hit the Character of your new Saint.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: And then their Dress, Gilliflower.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Oh! 'Tis an Abomination to look like a Gentleman; long Hair is wicked and Cavalierish, a Periwig is flat Popery, the Disguise of the Whore of Babylon; handsom Cloaths, or lac'd Linnen, the very Tempter himself, that debauches all their Wives and Daughters: therefore, the diminutive Band, with the Hair of the Reformation Cut, beneath which, a Pair of large sanctify'd Souses appear, to declare to the World, they had hitherto escap'd the Pillory, tho' deserv'd it as well as Pryn.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Have a Care what you say, Gilliflower.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Why Madam, we have no Informers here.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam, here's Old Noll's Wife desires Admittance to your Hon— your Highness.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Bid the poor Creature wait without, I'le do her what good I can for her Husbands sake, who first infus'd Politiques into me, by which I may boast I have clim'd to Empire.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: So, her Madness runs in that Vein I see. Aside.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Alack Madam, I think she's coming.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: without. Does she keep state in the Divel's Name, and must I wait!

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Heav'ns! I shall be scandaliz'd by the godly, Dear Gilliflower, conceal my Cavalier; I wou'd not have a Cavalier seen with me for all the World.— Step into my Cabinet— Ex. Gill. and Lov.

div.stage: Enter La. Cromwel, held back by a Man.— to them Gilliflower.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: Unhand me Villain— 'twas not long since a Rudeness Sir like this had forfeited thy Head.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: What wou'd the Woman?

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: The Knave, the perjur'd Villain thy Husband, byth' Throat, thou proud, imperious Baggage; to make me wait? who's Train thou hast been proud to bear— how durst thou, after an Affront like this, trust thy false Face within my Fingers reach? that Face, that first bewitch't the best of Husbands from me, and tempted him to sin.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: I beseech your Highness retire, the Woman's mad.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Highness, in the Devil's name, sure 'tis not come to that; no, I may live to see thy Cuckold hang'd first, his Politicks are yet too shallow, Mistris.
Heav'ns! Did my Husband make him Lord for this? raise him to Honour,
Trusts, Commands, and Councels,
To ruine all our Royal Family,
Betray'd young Richard, who had reign'd in Peace
But for his Perjuries and Knaveries;
And now he sooths my Son in Law, soft Fleetwood,
With empty hopes of Pow'r, and all the while
To make himself a King:
No, Minion, no; I yet may live to see
Thy Husband's Head o'th top of Westminster
Before I see it circled in a Crown.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: I pity the poor Creature.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Ungrateful Traytor as he is,
Not to look back upon his Benefactors;
But he, in lieu of making just Returns,
Reviles our Family, prophanes our Name,
And will in time render it far more odious
Than ever Needham made the great Heroicks.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Alas, it weeps, poor Woman!

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Thou ly'st, false Strumpet, I scorn to shed a Tear
For ought that thou can'st do or say to me;
I've too much of my Husband's Spirit in me.
Oh, my dear Richard, had'st thou had a grain on't,
Thou and thy Mother ne'r had fall'n to this.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: His Father sure was seeking of the Lard when he was got.

div.stage: Enter La. Fleetwood, her Train borne.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Where is this perjur'd Slave, thy Wittal Lord?
Dares he not shew his Face, his guilty Face,
Before the Person he has thus betray'd?

sp.speaker: L. Fleet.
sp.l: Madam, I hope you mistake my honour'd Lord Lambert, I believe he designs the Throne for my dear Lord.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Fond Girl, because he has the Art of fawning,
Dissembling to the height, can sooth and smile,
Profess, and sometimes weep:—
No, he will betray him, as he did thy Brother;
Richard the Fourth was thus deluded by him.
No, let him swear and promise what he will,
They are but Steps to his own ambitious End;
And only makes the Fool, thy credulous Husband
A silly deluded Property.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: My honour'd Mother, I am glad to find you here, I hope we shall reconcile things between ye. Verily, we shou'd live in brotherly Love together; come, ingeniously, you shall be Friends, my Lady Mother.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Curse on th' occasion of thy being a Kin to me.

sp.speaker: Flee.
sp.p: Why, an please ye forsooth Madam?

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: My Daughter had a Husband,
Worthy the Title of my Son in Law:
Ireton! my best of Sons: he'd Wit and Courage,
And with his Councels, rais'd our House to Honours,
Which thy impolitick Easiness pulls down:
And whilst you shou'd be gaining Crowns and Kingdoms
Art poorly couzening of the World with fruitless Prayers.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Nay, I'll warrant you Madam, when there is any gadly mischief to be done, I am as forward as the best, but 'tis good to take the Lard along with us in every thing. I profess ingeniously, as I am an honest man, verily— ne're stir— I shall act as becomes a good Christian.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: A Good Coxcombe.
Dost thou not see her reverend Highness there,
That Minion now assumes that glorious Title
I once, and my Son Richard's Wife enjoy'd,
Whilst I am call'd the Night Mare of the Commonwealth?
But wou'd I were, I'd so hag-ride the perjur'd Slaves
Who took so many Oaths of true Allegiance
To my great Husband first, and then to Richard—
Who, whilst they reign'd, were most illustrious,
Most high and mighty Princes; whilst fawning Poets
Write Panegyricks on 'em: And yet no sooner was
The wonderous Heroe dead, but all his glorious
Titles fell to Monster of Mankind, Murderer
Of Piety, Traytor to Heav'n and Goodness.

sp.speaker: Flee.
sp.l: Who calls him so? Pray take their Names down: I profess ingeniously, forsooth Madam, verily I'll order 'em, as I am here I will.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Thou, alas they scorn so poor a thing as thou.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.l: Do they ingeniously? I'll be even with 'em, forsooth Mother, as I am here I will, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: I wou'd there were an end of our disgrace and shame, which is but just begun, I fear.—
What will become of that fair Monument
Thy careful Father did erect for thee, to La. Fleetw.
Yet whilst he liv'd, next to thy Husband Ireton?
Lest none shou'd do it for thee after he were dead?
The Malice of proud Lambert will destroy all.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: I profess, Madam, you mistake my good Lord Lambert, he's an honest man, and fears the Lard; he tells me I am to be the man; verily he do's, after all's done.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Yes, after all's done, thou art the man to be pointed at.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Nay, ingeniously, I scorn the words, so I do: I know the great Work of Salvation to the Nation is to be wrought by me, verily.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Do, Cant on, till Heav'n drop Kingdoms in thy mouth: dull, silly Sot, thou ruine of our Interest: thou fond, inccorrigible, easie Fool.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: My Lord, the Committee of Safety waits your coming.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Why, law you now, forsooth,— I profess verily, you are ingeniously the hardest of belief— tell the honourable Lords I'm coming: Go, Lady mother, go home with my Wife; and verily you'll see things go to your wish.— I must to Coach.—

sp.speaker: L. Fleet.
sp.p: Madam your humble Servant. to La. Lam.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Honour'd Lady I kiss your hands. Ex. Crom. Fleet. and La. Fleet.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Was this the thing that is to be Protector?
This little snivelling Fellow rule three Kingdoms?
But leave we Politicks, and fall to Love,
Who deals more Joyes in one kind, happy moment
Than Ages of Dull Empire can produce.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Oh Gods! Shall I who never yielded yet,
But to him to whom three Kingdoms fell a Sacrifice,
Surrender at first Parly?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Perhaps that Lover made ye gayer Presents,
But cou'd not render you a Heart all love,
Or mind embyass'd in Affairs of Blood.
— I bring no Guilt to fright ye from my Embraces,
But all our hours shall be serene and soft.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Ah, Gilliflower, thy Aid, or I'm lost;
Shall it be said of me in after Ages
When my great Fame 'mongst Queens shall be recorded,
That I, ah Heav'ns! regardless of my Countries Cause,
Espous'd the wicked Party of its Enemies,
The Heathenish Heroicks! ah, defend me!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Nay— by all that's—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Ah hold! Do not prophane my Ears with Oaths or Execrations, I cannot bear the sound.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Nay, nay,— by Heav'n I'll not depart your lodgings, till that soft
Love that playes so in your Eyes give me a better proof— by—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Oh hold, I dye, if you proceed in this Abomination!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why do you force me to't? d'ye think to put me off with such a Face— such lips,— such smiles— such Eyes— and every Charm— You've made me mad, and I shall swear my Soul away, if disappointed now.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Ah, save the Gentleman's Soul, I beseech ye, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: I'm much inclin'd to Acts of Piety— leaning on him, smiling. He goes to lead her out, Enter La. Desbro.
And you have such a Power, that howe're I incommode my Honour—
— Desbro here! how unseasonably she comes?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.l: Cry mercy, Madam, I'll withdraw a while.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Ah Desbro! thou art come— in the most lucky minute— I was just on the point of falling— As thou say'st, these Heroicks have the strangest Power—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: I never knew a Woman cou'd resist 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: No marvel then, our Husbands use 'em so, betray 'em, banish 'em, sequester, murder 'em, and every way disarm 'em.—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: But their Eyes Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Ay, their Eyes Desbro; I wonder our Lords shou'd take away their Swords, and let 'em wear their Eyes.

sp.speaker: La. Desbro.
sp.p: I'll move it to the Committee of Safety, Madam, those Weapons shou'd be taken from 'em too.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Still they'll have some to be reveng'd on us.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Ay, so they will; My Lord says, a Cavalier is a kind of Hidra, knock him o'th' Head as often as you will, he has still one to peep up withall.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam, here's Mr. Freeman to speak with your Honour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That's a Friend of mine Madam, and 'twou'd be unnecessary he saw your Highness and I together: let us withdraw—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Withdraw, why, What will Desbro say?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: O Madam, I know your Vertue and your Piety too well to suspect your Honour wrongfully? 'tis impossible a Lady that goes to a Conventicle twice a day, besides long Prayers and lowd Psalm-singing, shou'd do any thing with an Heroick against her Honour. Your known Sanctity preserves you from Scandal.— But here's Freeman— Puts 'em in.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So Madam— you are very kind—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.l: My charming Freeman, this tedious day of Absence has been an
Age in love! How hast thou liv'd without me?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Like one condemn'd, sad and disconsolate,
And all the while you made your Husband happy.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.l: Name not the beastly Hypocrite, thou know'st
I make no other use of him,
But a dull Property to advance our Love.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And 'tis but Iustice, Maria, he sequester'd me of my whole Estate, because, he said, I took up Arms in Ireland, on Noble Ormond's Side; nay, hir'd Rogues, perjur'd Villains— Witnesses with a Pox, to swear it too; when at that Time, I was but eight years old: But I 'scapt as well as all the Gentry and Nobility of England. To add to this, he takes my Mistress too.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: You mistake, my lovely Freeman; I marryed only thy Estate, the best Composition I cou'd make for thee, and I will pay it back with Interest too.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You wou'd suspect my love then, and swear that all the Adoration I pay you, were, as we do to Heaven, for Int'rest only.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: How you mistake my love, but do so still, so you will let me give these— Proofs of it. Gives him Gold.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Thus like Atlante, you drop Gold in my Pursuit
To love, I may not over-take you:
What's this, to giving me one happy minute?
Take back your Gold, and give me currant love,
The Treasure of your Heart, not of your Purse,—
When shall we meet Maria?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: You know my leasure Hours are when my honourable Lord is busied in Affairs of State, or at his Prayers; from which long-winded Exercise I have of late withdrawn my self: three Hours by the Clock he prays extempory, which is, for National and Houshold Blessings: for the first— 'tis to confound the Interest of the King, that the Lard wou'd deliver him, his Friends, Adherers and Allies, wheresoever scatter'd about the Face of the whole Earth, into the Clutches of the righteous: Press 'em good Lard, even as the Vintager doth the Grape in the Wine-Press, till the Waters, and gliding Chanels are made red with the Blood of the wicked. In a Tone.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And grant the faithful to be mighty, and to be strong in Persecution; and more especially, Ah! I beseech thee confound that malignant Tory Freeman— that he may never rise up in Judgment against thy Servant, who has taken from him his Estate, his Sustinance, and Bread; give him Grace of thy infinite Mercy, to hang himself, if thy People can find no zealous Witnesses to swear him to the Gallows legally. Ah, we have done very much for thee Lard, thou shoud'st consider us thy Flock, and we shou'd be as good to thee in another thing. In a Tone.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Thou hit'st the zealous Twang right; sure thou hast been acquainted with some of'em.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Damn 'em, no; what honest Man wou'd keep 'em Company, where harmless Wit and Mirth's a Sin, laughing scandalous, and a merry Glav, Abomination.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Yes, if you drink Healths my wicked Brother; otherwise, to be silently drunk, to be as abusive and satyrical as you please, upon the Heroicks, is allowable— for laughing, indeed 'tis not so well; but the precise Sneere and Grin is lawful; no swearing indeed, but lying and dissimulation in abundance— I'll assure you, they drink as deep, and entertain themselves as well with this silent way of lewd Debauchery, as you with all your Wit and Mirth, your Healths to the Royal Family.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, I confess, 'tis a great Pleasure to cheat the World.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: 'Tis Power, as divine Hobs calls it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But what's all this to Love? Where shall we meet anon?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: I'll tell you, that will please you as well.— Your Friend is within, with her Highness that shall be, if the Divel and her Husband's Politicks agree about the matter.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, has my cautious Railer manag'd matters so sleyly?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: No, No, the Matter was manag'd to his Hand: You see how Heav'n brings things about, for the Good of your Party; this Bus'ness will be worth him, at least a thousand pound a Year, or two, well manag'd.— But see, my Ladies Woman.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Oh Madam, my Lord! Running cross the Stage into her Ladies Chamber.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Death, how shall I bring my Friend off? He'll certainly be ruin'd.

div.stage: Enter Gill. Lov. and La. Lam.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Madam, he's coming up.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam, for my self I care not, but much concern'd for you.

div.stage: La. Lam. takes two Papers out of her Pock. and gives 'em to Lov. and Free.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Here, take these two Petitions, each of you one,— Poor Fellows— you may be gone, your Petitions will not be granted.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How now, my Dear, what Petitions?— Friends, what's your Bus'ness?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: 'Tis enough we know their Business Love, we are sufficient to dispatch such Suters, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Pardon me, my Dear, I thought no harm; but I saw you frown, and that made me concern'd.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p:
Frown! 'Twou'd make any Body frown, to hear the Impudence of Gentlemen, these Cavaliers;— wou'd you think it my Dear, if this Fellow
has not the Impudence to petition for the Thirds of his Estate again, so justly taken from him for bearing Arms for the Man?—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Nay, I ' am inform'd, that they, but two Nights ago, in a Tavern, Drunk a Health to the Man too.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How durst you, Sirrah, approach my Lady with any such sawcy Address, you have receiv'd our Answer.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Death, I've scarce Patience. Aside.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: We knew, my Lord, the Influence your Ladies have over you, and Women are more tender and compassionate naturally, than Men; and Sir, 'tis hard for Gentlemen to starve.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Have you not able Limbs, can ye not work—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Persons of our Education work!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Starve or beg then.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Education, why, I'll warrant there was that young Creature they call the Duke of Glocester, was as well educated as any Lad in the Parish, and yet you see he should have been bound Prentice to a handy Crafts Trade, but that our Lords cou'd not spare Money to bind him out, and so they sent him to beg beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Death, I shall do Mischief: not all the Joy she gave me but now, can attone for this Blasphemy against the Royal Youth.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Patience— Well my Lord, we find you are obdurate, and we'll withdraw.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Do so: And if you dare presume to trouble us any more, I'll have you whip'd, d'e hear.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Madam, I'll take my leave of your Ladiship. Ex. Lov. Free. & L. Des.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: My Lord, 'twas I that ought to threaten 'em— but you'r so forward still— what makes you from the Committee?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I left some Papers behind.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: And they'll make use of your Absence to set up Fleetwood King.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I'll warrant ye my Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: You'll warrant? you're a Fool and a Coxcomb; I see I must go my self, there will be no bus'ness done 'till I thunder 'em together: They want Old Oliver amongst 'em, his arbitrary Nod cou'd make ye all tremble; when he wanted Power or Money, he need but Cock in Parliament, and lay his hand upon his Sword, and cry, I must have Money, and had it, or kick'd ye all out a doors: And you are so mealy mouth'd, you cannot Cock for a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Dear, I can do as good a thing for a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: You can do nothing as you shou'd do't: You want Old Oliver's Brains, Old Oliver's Courage, and Old Oliver's Counsel: Ah, what a politick Fellow was little Sir Anthony! What a Head-peice was there! What a plaguy Fellow Old Thurlo, and the rest: But get ye back, and return me Protector at least, or never hope for Peace again.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Soul trouble not thy self, go in—
With mine, no Power can equal be,
And I will be a King to humour thee. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene I. A Council Chamber, great Table, Chairs, and Papers.
div.stage: Enter two Clarks, who lay Papers in Order, and Door-keeper.

sp.speaker: Door.
sp.p: COme, Haste, Haste, the Lords are coming;— keep back there, room for the Lords, room for the honourable Lords: Heav'n bless your Worships Honours.

div.stage: Enter Lambert, Fleetwood, Whitlock, Wariston, discoursing earnestly; to them Duckenfield, Cobbet, Hewson, Desbro, and others; Duck takes Wariston by the Hand, and talks to him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Bread a gued Gentlemen, I's serv'd the Commonwealth long and faithfully; I's turn'd and turn'd to aud Interest and aud Religions that turn'd up Trump, and wons a me, but I's get naught but Bagery by my Sol; I's noo put in for a Pansion as well as rest o ya Loones.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: What we can serve you in my Lord, you may command.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: And I too my Lord, when the Government is new moulded.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons Sirs, and I's sa moold it; 'twas ne're sa moolded sin the Dam boond the Head on't.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: I know there are some ambitious Spirits that are for a single Person; but we'll have hot work e're yield to that.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: The faud Diel take 'em then for Archibald; 'tis warse than Monarchy.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: A thousand Times: Have we with such Industry, been pulling down Kings of the Royal Family, to set up Tyrants of our own, of mean and obscure Birth? No, if we're for a single Person, I'm for a lawful one.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons and ya have spoken aud my Lord, so am I.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: But Lambert has a busie, haughty Spirit, and thinks to carry it; but we'll have no single Person.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Nor I, ods Bread; the faud Diel brest the Wem of Lambert, or any single Person in England. I's for yare Interest my gued Lords. Bowing.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord Wariston, will you please to assume the Chair.

div.stage: Enter Loveless, Freeman, and others with Petitions.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Ah, my gued Loord, I's yare most obedient humble Servant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hum, Hum.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: My Lords and Gentlemen, we are here met together in the Name of the Lard—

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Yea, and I hope we shall hang together as one man.— A Pox upon your preaching. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: — And hope this days great work will be for his Praise and Glory.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: ‛ Bating long Graces my Lord, we are met together for the Bus'ness of the Nation, to settle it, and to establish a Government.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Yea, verily: And I hope you will all unanimously agree, it shall be your unworthy Servant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: What else my Lord?

sp.speaker: Flee.
sp.p: And as thou Lard has put the Sword into my hand—

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: So put it into your Heart— My Lord, to do Justice.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: I'd rather see it there than in your Hand. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: For, we are, as it were, a Body without a Head; or, to speak more learnedly, an Animal, unanimate.

sp.speaker: Hus.
sp.p: My Lord, let us use, as little as we can, the language of the Beast; hard Words, none of your Eloquence, it savoureth of Monarchy.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord, you must give men of Quality leave to speak in a Language more Gentile and Courtly than the ordinary sort of mankind.

sp.speaker: Hew.
sp.p: My Lord, I am sorry to hear there are any of Quality amongst this Honourable Dissembly. stands up.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Assembly, my Lord—

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Well, you know my meaning; or if there be any such, I'm sorry they shou'd own themselves of Quality.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: How, own themselves Gentlemen? Death Sir, d' ye think we were all born Coblers?

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Or if you were not, the more the pitty, for little England, I say. in heat.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Verily, my Lords, Brethren shou'd not fall out, it is a scandal to the Good Cause, and maketh the Wicked rejoyce.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons and theys garr the Loosey Proverb on't te, When Loons gang together by th' Luggs, gued men get their ene.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He, he, he.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: He calls you Knaves by craft, my Lords.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Bread a gued, tak't among yee Gentlemen, I's ment weele.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: I profess, my Lord Wariston, you make my hair stand an end to hear how you swear.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons, my Loord, I's sware as little as your Lordship, only I's sware out, and ya swallow aud.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: There's a Bone for you to pick, my Lord.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He, he, he.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: We give my Lord Wariston leave to jest.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: But what's this to the Government all this while? a dad I shall sit so late, I shall have no time to visit my Horses, therefore proceed to the Point.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Ay, to the Point, my Lords; the Gentleman that spoke last spoke wll.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Well sed Brother, I see you will in time speak properly.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: But to the Government, my Lords? beats the Table.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Put 'em off o' this Discourse, my Lord. aside to War.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: My Lord Wariston, move it, you are Speaker.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: The Diel a me, Sirs, and noo ya talk of a Speaker, I's tell ye a blithe Tale.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Ingeniously my Lord, you are to blame to swear so.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Your Story, my Lord.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: By my Solmon, and there was a poor Woman the other day beg'd ot'h' Carle the Speaker, but he'd give her nought unlas she'd lat a feart; wons at last a feart she lat, Ay marry, quoth the woman, noo my Rump has a Speaker te.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He, he, he.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: But to our Bus'ness—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Bus'ness; ay, there's the thing, I've a world on't. I shou'd go and bespeak a pair of Mittens and Shears for my Hedger and Shearer, a pair of Cards for my Thrasher, a Sythe for my Mower, and a Skreen-fan for my Lady Wife, and many other things; my Head's full of bus'ness— I cannot stay.—

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Fy my Lord, will you neglect the bus'ness o'th' day? we meet to oblige the Nation, and gratifie our Friends.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Nay, I'll do any thing, so I may rise time enough to see my Horses at night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Damn 'em, what stuff's here for a Council-Table?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Where are our English Spirits, that can be govern'd by such Dogs as these?—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Clark, Read the Heads of what past at our last sitting.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: In the first place, I must mind your Lordships tol consider those that have been gued Members in the Commonwelth.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: We shall not be backward to gratifie any that have serv'd the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: There's Money enough; we have taxt the Nation high.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Yes, if we knew where to find it: however read.

sp.speaker: Clark
sp.p: reads. To Walter Walton Draper, six thousand nine hundred twenty nine pounds six shillings and five pence, for Blacks for his Highness Funeral.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: For the Devil's, put it down for Oliver Cromwel's Funeral: We'll have no Records rise up in Judgment for such a Villain.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How the live Asses kick the dead Lion? aside.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Hark ye, my Lords, We sit here to reward Services done to the Commonwealth; let us consider whether this be a Service to the Commonwealth or not?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: However, we'll give him Paper for't.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Ay, let him get his money when he can.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Paper's not so dear, and the Clerk's pains will be rewarded.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Right, my gued Loord, 'sbred, that Cromwel was th' faudest limmer Loon that ever cam intol our Country, the faud Diel has tane him by th' luggs for robbing our Houses and Land.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: No swearing, my Lord.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Weel, weel, my Loord, I's larne to profess and lee as weel as best on ya.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: That may bring you profit, my Lord— but Clerk proceed.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: reads. To Walter Frost, Treasurer of the Contingencies, twenty thousand pounds: to Thurloe, Secretary to his Highness—

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: To old Nol.—

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: reads Old Nol, ten thousand pound, for unknown Service done the Commonwealth— to Mr. Hutchinson Treasurer of the Navy, two hundred thousand pounds—

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Two hundred thousand pound; Owns what a Sum's there?— Marry it came from the Mouth of a Cannon sure.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: reads. A Present to the Right Honourable and truly Vertuous Lady, the Lady Lambert, for Service done the late Protector.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Again— say Cromwel.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: — Cromwel— six thousand pound in Iacobus's.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: 'Sbread, sike a Sum wou'd make me honour the face of aud Iemmy.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: To Mr. Ice six thousand pound; to Mr. Loether late Secretary to his High—

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: To Oliver Cromwel say, can you not obey Orders?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: — Secretary to Oliver Cromwel— two thousand nine hundred ninety nine pounds, for Intelligence and Information, and piously betraying the King's Liege People.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Haud, haud Sirs, Mary en ya gift se fast ya'll gif aud away fro poor Archibauld Iohnson.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: Speak for your self, my Lord; or rather my Lord, do you speak for him. to Lam

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Do you move it for him, and I'll do as much for you anon. aside to Whit.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: My Lord, since we are upon Gratifications,— let us consider the known Merits of the Lord Wareston, a Person of industrious mischiefs to the Malignant Party, and great Integrity to us, and the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Gued faith an I's ha been a trusty Trojon Sirs, what say you my very gued and gracious Loords?—

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: I scorn to let a Dog go unrewarded; and you, Sir, fawn so prettily, 'tis pity you shou'd miss Preferment.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: And so 'tis; come, come, my Lords, consider he was ever our Friend, and 'tis but reasonable we shou'd stich up one another's broken Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I'm not against it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Tis reason, 'tis reason.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Damn 'em, how they lavish out the Nation?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Scribe, pretha read my Paper—

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Have you a pertition there!

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: A Pitition, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Pshaw, You Scholards are so troublesom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Read the Substance of it. to the Clerk.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: That your Honours wou'd be pleas'd, in consideration of his Services, to grant to your Petitioner a considerable Sum of Money for his present supply.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Verily, order him two thousand pound—

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Two thousand poond? Bread a gued, and I's gif my Voice for Fleetwood. aside.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Two thousand; nay, my Lords, let it be three.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons, I lee'd, I leed; I's keep my Voice for Lambert.— gueds Benizon light on yar Sol, my gued Lord Lambert.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Three thousand pound, why such a Sum wou'd buy half Scotland.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons, my Lord, ya look but blindly on't then: time was, a mite on't had bought aud shoos in yar Stall, Brother, tho' noo ya so abound in Irish and Bishops Lands.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: You have nick'd him there, my Lord.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He, he, he.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Scribe— gang a tiny bit farther.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: — And that your Honours wou'd be pleas'd to confer an Annual Pension on him.—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Reason, I think; What say you my Lords of five hundred pound a year?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: The Diel swallow me, my Lord, ya won my heart.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: 'Tis very well— but out of what shall this be rais'd?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: We'll look what Malignants Estates are forfeit, undispos'd of— let me see— who has young Freeman's Estate?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: My Lord, that fell to me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: What all the fifteen hundred pound a year?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: A dad, and all little enough.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Devil do him good with it.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Had not the Lard put it into your hearts to have given me two thousand par an um out of Bishops Lands, and three thousand par an um out of the Marquess's Estate; how shou'd I have liv'd and serv'd the Common-wealth as I have done?

sp.speaker: Free.
