sp.p: A plague confound his Honour, he makes a hard shift to live on Eight thousand pound a year, who was born and bred a Hedger.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Patience, Friend.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I have been thinking— but I'll find out a way.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Or betray some honest Gentleman, on purpose to gratifie the Loone.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
And Gentlemen, I am bound in Honour and Conscience to speak in behalf of my Lord Whitlock; I think fit, if you agree with me, he shou'd
be made Constable of Windsor Castle, Warden of the Forrest, with the Rents, Perquisites, and Profits thereto belonging, nor can your Lordships confer a Place of greater Truth and Honour in more safe hands.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: I find he wou'd oblige all to his side. aside. Has he not part of the Duke of Buckingham's Estate already, with Chelsey House, and several other Gifts?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: He has dearly deserv'd 'em, he has serv'd our Interest well and faithfully.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: And he has been well paid sor't.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: And so were you, Sir, with several Lordships, and Bishops Lands, you were not born to, I conceive.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: I have not got it, Sir, by Knavish Querks in Law, a Sword that deals out Kingdoms to the brave, has cut out some small parcels of Earth for me, And what of this? stands up in a heat.

sp.speaker: Whit
sp.p: I think, Sir, he that talks well, and to'th purpose, may be as useful to the Commonwealth as he that fights well; Why do we keep so many else in Pension that ne'r drew Sword, but to talk, and rail at the Malignant Party; to libel and defame 'em handsomly, with pious, useful Lyes:
sp.l: Which pass for Gospel with the common Rabble,
And Edifie more than Hugh Peters's Sermons?
And make Fools bring more Grist to th' publick Mill:
Then Sir— to wrest the Law to our convenience
Is no small, inconsiderate Work?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: And which you may be hang'd for very shortly— aside.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis granted, my Lord, your Merit's infinite,—
We made him Keeper of the Great Seal, 'tis true, 'tis Honour, but no Salary.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Ten thousand pound a year in Bribes will do as well.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Bribes are not so frequent now as in Old Noll's dayes.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, let us be brief and tedious, as the saying as, and humour one another; I'm for Whitlock's advance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I move for a Salary, Gentlemen, Scobel and other petty Clerks have had a thousand a year, my Lord sure merits more.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Why,— let him have two thousand then.

sp.speaker: Flee.
sp.p: I profess ingeniously, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Lordships— but, if I may be so bold to ask, from whence shall I receive it?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Out of the Customs.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Brotherly love ought to go along with us— but, under favour, when this is gone, where shall we raise new supplies?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We'll tax the Nation high, the City higher;
They are our Friends, our most obsequious Slaves,
Our Dogs, to fetch and carry, our very Asses—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And our Oxes, with the help of their Wives. aside.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Besides, the City's rich, and near her time, I hope, of being deliver'd.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons a gued, wad I'd the laying o her, she shou'd be sweetly brought to Bed, by my Sol.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: The City cares for no Scotch Pipers, my Lord.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: By my Sol, but she has danc'd after the gued Pipe of Reformation, when the Covenant Jigg gang'd maryly round Sirs.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: My Lords, here are some poor malignant Petitioners.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Oh, turn 'em out, here's nothing for 'em; these Fellows were petitioning my Lady to day— I thought she had given you a satisfactory Answer?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She did indeed, my Lord; but, 'tis a hard Case, to take away a Gentleman's Estate, without convicting him of any Crime.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Oh Sir! we shall prove that hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But to make sure Work, you'll hang a man first, and examine his Offence afterwards; a Plague upon your Consciences: my Friend here had a little fairer Play, your Villains, your Witnesses in Pension swore him a Collonel for our Glorious Master, of ever blessed Memory, at eight years old; a Plague upon their miracles.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Ingeniously, Sirrah, you shall be pillory'd for defaming our reverend Witnesses: Guards take 'em to your Custody both.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Damn it, I shall miss my Assignation with Lady Desbro; a Pox of your unncessary Prating, what shall I do? Guards take 'em away.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: And now, my Lords, we have finish'd the bus'ness of the Day. My good Lord Fleetwood, I am entirely yours, and at our next sitting shall approve my self your Creature.—

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: My good Lord, I am your submissive Vassal.

sp.speaker: Wariston.
sp.p: Wons my Lord, I scorn any man shou'd be mere yare Vassal than Archibald Iohnson. To Fleetwood.

div.stage: Enter La. Desbro. and Corporal in haste.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Seiz'd on, secur'd, was there no time but this? What made him at the Committee, or when there, why spoke he honest Truth? What shall I do, good Corporal Advise: take Gold, and see if you can corrupt his Guards, but they are better paid for doing mischief; yet try, their Consciences are large. Gives him Gold.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'll venture my Life in so good a Cause, Madam. Ex.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Madam here's Mr. Ananias Gogle, the Lay Elder of Clements Parish.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p:
Dam the sham Saint; am I now in Condition to be plagu'd with
his impertinent Non-sense?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Oh! Pray Madam hear him preach a little; 'tis the purest sport.—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Peace be in this Place.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: A blessed Hearing; he preaches nothing in his Conventicles, but Blood and Slaughter. Aside. What wou'd you Sir, I'm something busie now.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ah, the Children of the Elect have no Business, but the great work of Reformation? Yea verily, I say, all other Business is prophane, and diabolical, and divelish; Yea, I say, these Dressings, Curles, and shining Habilliments,— which take so up your time, your precious time; I say, they are an Abomination, yea, an Abomination in the sight of the Righteous, and serve but as an Ignis fatuus, to lead vain man astray.— I say again— Looking now and then behind on the Page.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: — You are a very Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: I say again, that even I, upright I, one of the new Saints, find a sort of a— a— a— I know not what,— a kind of a— Motion as it were— a stirring up— as a man may say, to Wickedness;— Yea, verily it corrupteth the outward man within me.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Is this your Business Sir, to rail against my Cloaths, as if you intended to preach me into my Primitive Nakedness again?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ah, the Naked Truth is best; but, Madam, I have a little work of Grace to communicate unto you, please you to send your Page away—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Withdraw— sure I can make my Party good with one wicked Elder: Now Sir— your Bus'ness. Ex. Page.— Be brief.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: As brief as you please— but— who in the sight of so much Beau— ty— can think of any Bus'ness but the Bus'ness!— Ah! hide those tempting Breasts,— Alack, how smoth and warm they are— Feeling 'em, and sneering.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: How now, Have you forgot your Function?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Nay, but I am mortal man also, and may fall seven times a day;— Yea verily, I may fall seven times a day:— Your Ladiships Husband is old,— and where there is a good Excuse for falling,— Ah, there the fall-ing— is excusable.— And might I but fall with your Ladiship,— might I, I say.—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: How, this from you, the Head o'th' Church militant; the very Pope of Presbytery?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Verily, the Sin lyeth in the Scandal; therefore, most of the discreet pious Ladies of the Age, chuse us, upright men, who make a Conscience of a secret, the Laiety being more regardless of their Fame.— In sober sadness, the Place— inviteth, the Creature tempting, and the Spirit very violent within me. Takes and ruffles her.

sp.speaker: L. Des.
sp.p: Who waits there?— I'm glad you have prov'd your self what I ever thought of all your pack of Knaves.

sp.speaker: An,
sp.p: Ah, Madam! Do not ruine my Reputation; there are Ladies of high Degree in the Commonwealth, to whom we find our selves most comforting; why might not you be one?— for, alas, we are accounted as able men in Ladies Chambers, as in our Pulpits; we serve both Functions— Enter Servants. Hah! her Servants— stands at a distance.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Shou'd I tell this, I shou'd not find belief. aside.

sp.speaker: Anan.
sp.p: Madam, I have another Errand to your Ladiship.— It is the Duty of my Occupation to catechize the Heads of every Family within my Diocese; and you must answer some sew Questions I shall ask— In the first place, Madam— Who made ye?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: So, from whoring to a zealous Catechism— who made me? what Insolence is this, to ask me Questions which every Child that lisps out words can answer.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: 'Tis our Method, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Your Impudence Sirrah— let me examine your Faith, who are so sawcy to take an account of mine— Who made you? But lest you shou'd not know, I will inform you: First, Heav'n made you a deform'd, ill favour'd Creature, then the Rascal your Father made you a Taylor, next, your Wife made you a Cuckold, and lastly, the Devil has made you a Doctor: and so get you gone for a Fool and a Knave all over.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: A man of my Coat affronted thus!

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: It shall be worse, Sirrah, my Husband shall know how kind you wou'd have been to him, because your Disciple and Benefactor, to have begot him a Babe of Grace for a Son and Heir.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Mistake not my pious meaning, most Gracious Lady.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: I'll set you out in your Colours: your impudent and Bloody Principles, your cheats, your Rogueries on honest men, through their kind, deluded Wives, whom you cant and goggle into a Belief, 'tis a great work of Grace to steal, and beggar their whole Families, to contribute to your Gormandizing, Lust, and Laziness; Ye Locusts of the Land, preach Nonsence, Blasphemy, and Treason, till you sweat again, that the Sanctifi'd Sisters my rub you down, to comfort and console the Creature.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ah! Am—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Sirrah, be gone, and trouble me no more— be gone— yet stay— the Rogue may be of Use to me— amongst the heap of Vice, Hypocrisie, and Devils that possess all your Party, you may have some necessary sin; I've known some honest, useful Villains amongst you, that will swear, profess, and lie devoutly for the Good Old Cause.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Yea verily, I hope there are many such, and I shou'd rejoyce, yea, exceedingly rejoyce, in any Gadly Performance to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: This is a pious Work: You are a Knave of Credit, a very Saint with the rascally Rabble, with whom your Seditious Cant more prevails, your precious hum and ha, and gifted Nonsence, than all the Rhetorick of the learn'd or honest.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Hah ●

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: — In fine, I have use of your Talent at present, there's one now in Confinement of the Royal Party— his name's Freeman.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: And your Ladiship wou'd have him dispatch'd; I conceive ye— but wou'd you have him dispatch'd privately, or by Form of Law? we've Tools for all uses, and 'tis a pious Work and meritorious.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Right: I wou'd indeed have him dispatch'd, and privately; but 'tis hither privately, hither, to my Chamber, privately, for I have private Bus'ness with him: D' ye start?— this must be done— for you can pimp I'm sure upon occasion, you've Tools for all uses; come, resolve, or I'll discover your bloody offer; Is your Stomach so queasie it cannot digest Pimping, that can swallow Whoring, false Oaths, Sequestration, Robbery, Rapes, and Murders daily?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Verily, you mistake my pious meaning; it is the Malignant I stick at; the Person, not the Office: and in sadness, Madam, it goeth against my tender Conscience to do any good to one of the Wicked.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: It must stretch at this time; go haste to the Guard, and demand him in my Husband's Name; here's something worth your Pains— having releas'd him, bring him to me, you understand me— go bid him be diligent, and as you behave your self, find my Favour; for know, Sir, I am as great an Hypocrite as you, and know the Cheats of your Religion too; and since we know one another, 'tis like we shall be true.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: But shou'd the man be missing, and I call'd to an account?—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: He shall be return'd in an hour; go, get you gon, and bring him, or— no more— Ex. Ana.
sp.l: For all degrees of Vices, you must grant
There is no Rogue like your Geneva Saint.

div.head: Scene I. Chamber, Candles and Lights.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: BY what strange Miracle, my dearest Freeman, wert thou set at Liberty?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: On the zealous Parole of Rabbie Ananias; that Rhetorick that can convert whole Congregations of well-meaning Block-heads, to errant Knaves, has now mollify'd my Keeper; I'm to be render'd back within this Hour: let's not, my dear Maria, lose the precious minutes this Reverend Hypocrite has given us.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Oh! You are very gay, have you forgot whose Prisoner you are, and that perhaps, e're many days are ended, they may hang you for High Treason against the Common-wealth? they never want good throw-stitch'd Witness, to do a Murder lawfully.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No matter; then I shall dye with Joy, Maria, when I consider, that you lov'd so well to give me the last Proof on't.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Are you in Earnest, Freeman, and wou'd you take what Honour will not suffer me to grant?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Honour's a poor Excuse: Your Heart and Vows (your better part) are mine; you've only lent your Body out to one whom you call Husband, and whom Heav'n has mark'd for Cuckoldom. Nay, 'tis an Act of honest Loyalty, so to revenge our Cause; whilst you were only mine, my honest Love thought it a Sin to press these Favours from you; 'twas injuring my self as well as thee; But now we only give and take our Right.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: No more, my Husband's old.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Right my Dear Maria;— and therefore,—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: — May possibly dye.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: He will be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: — I hope so— either of which, will do our Business:— Unreasonable Freeman, not to have Patience till my Husband be hang'd a little.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But what if Destiny put the Change upon us, and I be hang'd instead of Desbro?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Why then thou art not the first Gallant Fellow that has dy'd in the Good and Royal Cause; and a small Taste of Happiness will but turn thee off the Ladder with the sadder Heart.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Hast thou the Conscience, lovely as thou art,
To deal out all thy Beauty to a Traytor?
Is not this Treason of the highest Nature,
To rob the Royal Party of such Treasure
And give it to our mortal Enemies:
For Shame, be wise and just,
And do not live a Rebel to our Cause;
'Tis Sin enough, to have Society with such a wicked Race.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: But I am marryed to him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So much the worse, to make a League and Covenant with such Villains, and keep the sinful Contract; a little harmless Lying and Dissimulation I'll allow thee, but to be right down honest, 'tis the Devil.

sp.speaker: L. Des.
sp.p: This will not do; it never shall be said I've been so much debauch'd by Conventickling to turn a Sainted Sinner: No, I'm true to my Allegiance still, true to my King and Honour. Suspect my Loyalty when I lose my Virtue; a little Time, I'm sure, will give me honestly into thy Arms, if thou hast Bravery show it in thy Love.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You will o'recome, and shame me every way;— but when will this Change come? And till it do, what Pawn will you give me? I shall be happy then.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: My Honour, and that Happiness you long for; and take but two Months Time for their Redemption.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How greedily I'll seize the Forfeiture!

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: But what am I like to get if this Change do come?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A Slave, and whatever you please to make of him.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Who knows, in such a universal Change, how you may alter too?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I'll give ye Bond and Vows, unkind Maria;— Here, take my hand— Be it known unto all Men, by these Presents, that I Iohn Freeman of London, Gent. acknowledge my self in debt to Maria Desbro, the Sum of one Heart, with an incurable Wound; one Soul, destin'd hers from it's first Being; and one Body, whole, sound, and in perfect Health; which I here promise to pay to the said Maria, upon Demand, if the aforesaid Iohn Freeman be not hang'd before such Demand made. Whereto, I set my Hand,— and seal it with my Lips.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: And I, in Consideration of such Debt, do freely give unto the abovesaid Iohn Freeman the Heart and Body of the abovesaid Maria Desbro, with all Appurtenances thereto belonging, whenever it shall please Heav'n to bring my Husband fairly to the Gallows. in a tone.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Amen.— kiss the Book— Kisses her.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Hah! that's Ananias sure; some Danger's near, the necessary Rascal gives us Notice of.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'tis so, what wou'dst thou have me do?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: thou art undone if seen.— Here, step within this Curtain. He goes.

div.stage: Enter Ananias, humming, and spreading his Cloak wide; Desbro behind him, puffing in a Chafe.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ads nigs, what a Change is here like to be,— puff puff— we have manag'd matters sweetly— to let the Scotch General undermine us; puff, puff.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Nothing Cockey, nothing, but that we are like to return to our first nothing.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Yea verily, when our times come; but ah, the great work of Reformation is not yet fully accomplished, which must be wrought by the Saints, and we cannot spare one of them until the Work be finish'd.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Yea, yea, it is finished I doubt, puff, puff; fye, fye, what a Change is here!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Patience, ah, 'tis a precious Virtue!—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Patience Sir! what, when I shall lose so many fine Estates which did appertain to the Wicked; and which, I trusted, had been establish'd ours; and tell'st thou me of Patience! puff, puff. walking fast.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: How lose 'em Sir? Handle the matter with Patience; I hope the Committee of Safety, or the Rump, will not do an illegal thing to one of the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: No, No, I have been a trusty Knave to them, and so I have found them all to me: but Monk! Monk! O that ever we shou'd be such blind Fools to trust an honest General!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Patience Sir, What of him!

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: I just now receiv'd private Intelligence, he's coming out of Scotland. with his Forces.— puff, puff.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Why, let him come a Gads Name, we have those will give him a civil Salute, if he mean not honourably to the Commonwealth. Patience Sir.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: But if he prove the stronger, and shou'd chance to be so great a Traytor to us to bring in the Man— the King?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: How, the King Husband; the great Heroick?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Death, this Woman is a Sybill? Ah, Noble Monk!

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Hum— the King!—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah, and with the King, the Bishops; and then, where's all our Church and Bishops Lands! Oh! undone.— puff puff.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: How, bring in the King and Bishops! my righteous Spirit is raised too:— I say, I will excommunicate him for one of the Wicked; yea, for a prophane Heroick, a Malignant, a Tory,— a— I say, we will surround him, and confound him with a mighty Host; yea, and fight the Lards Battel with him; yea, we will.—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Truckle to his Pow'r.— puff, puff.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Nay, I say verily, nay; for, in Sadness, I will dye in my Calling.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: So I doubt shall I— which is Plowing, Hedging, and Ditching.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Yea, we have the Sword of the Righteous in our hand, and we will defend the mighty Revenues of the Church, which the Lard hath given unto his People, and chosen ones— I say, we will defend—

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah, Patience, Sir, ah, 'tis a pious Virtue—

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ah, it is Zeal in one of us, the out-goings of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sir, Will you go down to Prayers? the Chaplain waits.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.l: No, no, Boy, I am too serious for that Exercise,
I cannot now dissemble, Heav'n forgive me.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: How, Sir, not dissemble— ah, then you have lost a great Vertue indeed, a very great Vertue; ah, let us not give away the Good Old Cause— but, as we have hitherto maintain'd it by Gadly cozenage, and pious frauds, let us persevere— ah, let us persevere to the end; let us not lose our Heritage for a Mess of Pottage, that is, let us not lose the Cause for Dissimulation and Hypocrisie, those two main Engines that have carry'd on the great Work.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Verily, you have prevailed, and I will go take counsel of my pillow: Boy— call my man to undress me— I'll to bed, for I am sick at heart. Ex. Tom. Page.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Death, what shall I do now? Des. walks, she whispers Ana.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: You must get my man off, or we're undone.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Madam, be comforted, Heaven will bring all things about for our advantage.— as Des. turns.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: But he's behind the Curtains man— Des. turns from 'em.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ah, let Providence alone— spreads his cloak wide and goes by degrees towards the Bed. — Your pious Lady, Sir, is doubtful, but I will give her ample satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Ah do, Mr. Ananias, do, for she's a good and a vertuous Lady, certo she is. goes close to the Bed-post, and speaks over his shoulder.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Get ye behind my cloak—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, your Counsel and Assistance is very comfortable,

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: We shou'd be helps meet to one another, Madam.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Alack, good man ● La. Des. goes to cokes her Husb.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Ay, my Dear, I am so much oblig'd to him, that I know not without thy thy aid, how to make him amends.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So this is the first Cloak of Zeal I ever made use of. An. going, spreading his cloak to the door, Freeman behind goes out.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: Good Lady give him this twenty pieces, a dad he worthily deserves 'em. gives her Gold.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Indeed, and so he does, Dear, if thou knew'st all.
— What say you now, do I not improve in Hypocrisie? and shall I not in time make a precious member of your Church? to Ana.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.l: Verily, your Ladiship is most ingenious and expert,
— Sir, I most humbly take my leave. Ex. Ananias.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord Lambert has sent in all haste for you, you must attend at his house immediately.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: So, he has heard the News— I must away— let my Coach be ready— Ex. Des.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: How unlucky was this that Freeman shou'd be gone— Sirrah, run, and see to o'retake him, and bring him back. Ex. all.

div.head: SCENE 2. A fine Chamber.
div.stage: Enter Gilliflower and Loveless, by dark, richly drest.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Where am I, Gilliflower?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: In my Ladies Apartment, Sir, she'll be with you presently; you need not fear betraying, Sir, for I'll assure you I'm an Heroick in my heart: my Husband was a Captain for his Majesty of ever blessed memory, and kill'd at Naseby, God be thanked, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What pity 'tis that thou shou'dst serve this Party?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: ‛ Bating her Principles, my Lady has good Nature enough to oblige a Servant; and truly Sir, my Vails were good in old Oliver's dayes; I got well by that Amour, between him and my Lady; the man was lavish enough.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, of the Nations Treasure— but, prithee tell me, Is not thy Lady mad, raving on Crowns and Kingdoms?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: It appears so to you, who are not us'd to the Vanity of the Party, but they are all so mad in their degree, and in the Fit they talk of nothing else Sir; we have to morrow a hearing, as they call it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What's that, a Conventicle?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, Ladies of the last Edition, that present their Grievances to the Council of Ladies, of which my Lady's Chief, which Grievances are laid open to the Committee of Safety, and so redress'd, or slighted, as they are.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That must be worth one's Curiosity, cou'd one but see't.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: We admit no man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, for so good a sight I will turn Woman.
I'll Act it to a hair.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: That wou'd be excellent.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, I must do't: the Novelty is rare— but I'm impatient— prethee let thy Lady know I wait.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: She's in Affairs of State, but will be here immediately; mean time, retire into her Cabinet, I'll send the Page with Lights, there you may repose, till my Lady comes, on the Pallat. she leads him out.

div.head: SCENE. A great Chamber of State,— and Canopy.
div.stage: And at a Table, seated Lambert, Fleetwood, Desbro, Hewson, Duckingfield, Wariston, Cobbet; all half drunk, with Bottles and Glasses on the Table; La. Lam. and La. Fleet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord Wariston, you are not merry to night.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons Mon, this Monk sticks in my Gullet, the muckle Diel pull him out by th' Lugs; the faud Loone will en spoyle ad our sport mon.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I thought I had enough satisfy'd all your Fears; the Army's mine, that is— 'tis yours, my Lords, and I'll employ it too so well for the Good of the Commonwealth, you shall have cause to commend both my Courage and Conduct: my Lord Wariston, will you accompany me?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Ah, my gued Lord, the Honour is too great! 'Tis not but I's dare fight my Lord, but I love not the limmer Loone, he has a villainous honest Face an's ene; I's kend him ence, and lik't him not; but I's drink tol yar gued Fortune; let it gang aboote, ene and ad Sirs. all drink.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: We'll leave all discourse of bus'ness, and give our selves to Mirth; I fancy good Success from this days Omen.

div.stage: Enter Gill. whispers La. Lam. she rises.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Waited so long!

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: And grew inpatient, and please your Highness; must I go tell him you cannot see him to Night.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Not for the World; my silly Politician will be
Busying himself in dull Affairs of State;
— Dull in Comparison of Love, I mean;
I never lov'd before; Old Oliver I suffer'd for my Interest,
And 'tis some Greatness, to be Mistress to the best;
But this mighty Pleasure comes A propo
To sweeten all the heavy Toyls of Empire.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: So it does, an't please your Highness.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Go, let him know I'm coming— Madam, I must beg your Pardon, you hear, my Lord to morrow goes on this great Expedition; and, for any thing we know, may fall a glorious Sacrifice to the Commonwealth; therefore, 'tis meet I offer up some Prayers for his Safety, and all my Leasure Hours 'twixt this and that, will be too few.— Your humble Servant Madam.— Ex. La. Lam.

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.p: My Dear, I'll leave you too, my Time of Devotion is come, and heav'n will stay for no Body; where are my People, is my Coach ready, or may Chair.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Go in your Chair my Love, lest you catch cold.

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.p: And light your Flambeaus,— I love to have my Chair surrounded with Flambeaus.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Your Chair is ready, Madam. She goes out, led by Fleet.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: What think ye now my Lords of settling the Nation a little; I find my Head swim with Politicks, and what ye call ums.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons, and wad ya settle the Nation when we real our selves?

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Who, pox shall we stand making Childrens Shoes all the year? No, No, let's begin to settle the Nation, I say, and go throw stich with our Work.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Right, we have no Head to obey; so that if this Scotch General do come, whilst we Dogs fight for the Bone, he runs away with it.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Shaw, we shall patch up matters with the Scotch General, I'll warrant you: However, here's to our next Head.— One and All.— all drink.

sp.speaker: Flee.
sp.p: Verily Sirs, this Health drinking savoureth of Monarchy, and is a Type of Malignancy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Bread, my Lord, no preaching o're yar Liquer, wee's now for a Cup o'th' Creature.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: In a gadly way you may, it is lawful.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Come, Come, we're dull, give us some Musick— Come my Lord, I'll give you a Song, I love Musick as I do a Drum, there's Life and Soul in't, call my Musick.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Yea, I am for any Musick, except an Organ.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: 'SBread Sirs, and I's for a Horn-pipe; I've a faud Theefe here shall dance ye dance tol a Horn-pipe, with any States man a ya'ad.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He, He, He.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: I know not what your faud Theefe can do; but, I'll hold you a Wager, Collonel Hewson, and Collonel Desbro, shall dance ye the Saints Jigg with any Sinner of your Kirk, or Field Conventickler.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons, and I's catch 'em at that sport, I's dance tol 'em for a Scotch Poond but farst yar Song, my Lord, I hope 'tis body, or 'tis not worth a Feart.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He, He, He.

lg.head: Song sung by Lord Lambert.
lg.l: A Pox of the States-man that's witty
That watches and Plots all the sleepless Night,
For Seditious Harangues to the Whigs of the City,
And piously turns a Traytor in spight.
Let him wrack and torment his lean Carrion,
Till Religion, King, Bishop, and Baron,
For the Publick Good, be quite rooted out.
Whilst we that are no Politicians,
But Rogues that are Resolute, bare-fac'd and Great,
Boldly head the rude Rabble in open Sedition,
Bearing all down before us in Church and in State.
Your Impudence is the best State trick,
And he that by Law means to rule,
Let his History with ours be related,
Tho' we prove the Knaves, 'tis he is the Fool.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: The Diel a me, wele sung my Lord, and gen aud Trads fail, yas make a quaint Minstrel.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He, He, He.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Noo Sirs, yar Dance? They fling Cushions at one another, and grin. Musick plays.— Mary Sirs, an this be yar dancing, tol dance and ne're stir Stap, the Diel lead the Donce for Archibald. When they have flung Cushions thus a while to the Musick Time, they beat each other from the Table, one by one, and fall into a godly Dance; after a while, Wariston rises, and dances ridiculously a while amongst them, then to the Time of the Tune, they take out the rest, as at the Cushion Dance, or in that Nature. Wariston being the last taken in, leads the rest. — Haud Minstrels hade; Bread a gued, I's fatch ad Ladies in— lead away Minstrels tol my Ladies Apartment. Musick playing before all.

div.head: SCENE. Flat.

sp.speaker: Pag. Cock.
sp.p: Here must I wait, to give my Lady Notice when my Lord approaches;— The fine Gentleman that is alone with her, gave me these two fine pieces of Gold, and bad me buy a Sword to fight for the King with-all; and I'm resolv'd to lay it all out in Sword, not a penny in Nickers, and fight for the Heroicks as long as I have a Limb, if they be all such fine Men as this within. But hark, sure I hear some coming.— Ex.

div.stage: Flat Scene draws off, discovers La. Lam. on a Couch, with Loveless, tying a rich Diamond Bracelet about his Arm; a Table behind with Lights, on which, a Velvet Cushion, with a Crown and Scepter cover'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This Present's too magnificent: Such Bracelets young Monarchs shou'd put on.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p:
Persons like me, when they make Presents, Sir, must do it for their Glory, not considering the merit of the Wearer; yet this, my charming
Loveless, comes short of what I ought to pay thy worth; comes short too of my Love.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You bless me, Madam—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: This the great Monarch of the World once ty'd about my Arm, and bade me wear it, till some greater man shou'd chance to win my Heart:
Thou art that man whom Love hath rais'd above him;
Whom every Grace and every Charm thou hast
Conspire to make thee mightier to my Soul;
And Oliver, Illustrious Oliver!
Was yet far short of thee.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: He was the Monarch then whose Spoils I triumph in.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: They were design'd for Trophies to the young and Gay.
Ah, Loveless! that I cou'd reward thy Youth
With something that might make thee more than man,
As well as give the best of Women to thee— rises, takes him by the hand, leads him to the Table. He starts.
— Behold this Gay, this wondrous Glorious thing.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Hah— a Crown— and Scepter!
Have I been all this while
So near the Sacred Reliques of my King!
And found no Awful motion in my blood,
Nothing that mov'd Sacred Devotion in me? kneels.
— Hail Sacred Emblem of Great Majesty,
Thou that hast circled more Divinity
Than the great Zodiack that surrounds the World.
I ne'r was blest with sight of thee till now,
But in much reverenc'd Pictures— rises and bows.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Is't not a lovely thing?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: There's such Divinity i'th very Form on't,
Had I been conscious I'd been near the Temple
Where this bright Relique of the Glorious Martyr
Had been inshrin'd, 'thad spoil'd my soft Devotion!
— 'tis Sacrilege to dally where it is;
A rude, a Sawcy Treason to approach it
With an unbended knee; for Heav's sake, Madam,
Let us not be profane in our Delights,
Either withdraw, or hide that Glorious Object.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Thou art a Fool, the very sight of this—
Raises my Pleasure higher,
Methinks I give a Queen into thy Arms:
And where I love I cannot give enough; softly.
— Wou'd I cou'd set it on thy Head for ever,
'Twou'd not become my simple Lord
The thousandth part so well. goes to put it on his Head, he puts it back

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Forbear, and do not play with holy things,
Let us retire, and love as Mortals shou'd,
Not imitate the Gods, and spoil our Joyes.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Lovely, and unambitious!
What hopes have I of all your promis'd Constancy,
Whilst this, which possibly 'ere long may adorn my Brow,
And ought to raise me higher in your Love,
Ought to transform you even to Adoration,
Shall poorly make you vanish from it's Lustre;
Methinks the very Fancy of a Queen
Is worth a thousand Mistress's of less Illustrious Rank.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: What every Pageant Queen? You might from thence infer
I'd fall in Love with every little Actress, because
She acts the Queen for half an hour,
But then the gawdy Robe is laid aside.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: I'll pardon the Comparison in you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I do not doubt your Power of being a Queen,
But trust, it will not last.
How truly brave wou'd your great Husband be,
If whilst he may, he pay'd this mighty Debt
To the Right Owner!
If whilst he has the Army in his Power
He made a true and lawful use of it,
To settle our great Master in his Throne;
And by an act so glorious raise his Name
Even above the Title of a King.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: You love me not, that wou'd perswade me from my Glory.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, the Lords are all got merry, as they call it, and are all dancing hither.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: What at their Oliverian Frolicks?— dear Loveless, withdraw, I wou'd not give the fond believing Fool a Jealousie of me.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Withdraw, Madam, 'tis impossible, he must run just into their mouthes.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Im ' ill at these Intrigues, being us'd to Lovers that still came with such Authority, that modestly my Husband wou'd withdraw— but Loveless is in danger, therefore take care he be not seen.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Heav'ns! they are coming, there's no retreat—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p:
Lye down on the Couch— and cover him you with the Foot-Carpet,— so, give me my Prayer-Book. He lyes down along on the Couch— they cover him with the Carpet: La. Lam. takes her Book, sits down on his Feet, and leans on the back of the Couch reading; Gill. stands at t'other end; they enter dancing— as before.
— What Insolence is this? do you not hear me, you— Sots— whom Gayety and Dancing do so ill become.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: singing. Welcom, Ione Sanderson, welcom, welcom. goes to take her out, she strikes him. Wons, Madam, that's no part o'th' dance.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: No, but 'tis part of a reward for your Insolence, which possibly your Head shall answer for.—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Pardon him, my dear, he meant no disrespect to thee.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: How dare you interrupt my Devotion, Sirrah?
Begon with all your filthy ill-bred Crew. Lam. sits down on Loveless.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My only dear, be patient; hah!
Something moves under me! Treason, Treason. He rises.

div.stage: Lov. rouls off, and turns Lam. over, the rest of the men run out crying Treason, Treason, overthrowing the Lights, putting 'em out.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Treason, Treason! my Lord, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Lights there, a Plot, a Popish Plot, lights. She groping about finds Lov. by his clothes knows him.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: The Crown, the Crown, guard the Crown!
— Here, take this Key, the next room is my Bed-chamber,
Secure your self a moment.— Ex. Loveless.
Lights there, the Crown— who art thou? takes hold of Lamb.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Ah, my Lord, what's the matter?—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay, my Lady, I ask you what's the matter, Enter Page with lights. By Heaven, all is not well: Hark ye, my fine she Politician, who was it you had hid beneath this Carpet?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Heav'ns! Do'st hear him, Gilliflower? Sure the Fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Alack, my Lord, Are you out of your Honourable Wits?
Heav'n knows, my Lady was at her Devotion.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Bawd, come, confess thy self to be one; at her Devotion, yes, with a He Saint.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Ah! Gad forbid the Saints shou'd be so wicked.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Hark ye, thou little snivelling Hypocrite, who hast no Virtue but a little Conduct in Martial Discipline; who hast by Perjuries, Cheats, and Pious Villanies, wound thy self up into the Rabbles Favour, where thou may'st stand, till some more great in Roguery remove thee from that height, or to the Gallows, if the King return. Hast thou the impudence to charge my Virtue?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I know not, Madam, whether that Virtue you boast were lost, or only stak't, and ready for the Gamester; but I am sure a Man was hid under this Carpet.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns, a Man!

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: A Lord, a Man? Are you sure 'twas a man, my Lord?
— Some Villanous Malignant, I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Alack, the Wickedness of these Heroicks, to hide under Carpets; why they'll have the Impudence to hide under our Petticoats shortly, if your Highness take 'em not down. To La. Lam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I do believe so; Death— a Cuckold; shall that black Cloud shade all my rising Fame?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Cuckold? Why is that Name so great a Stranger to ye,
Or has your rising Fame made ye forget
How long— that Cloud has hung upon your Brow?
— 'Twas once the height of your Ambition Sir,
When you— were a poor— sneeking Slave to Cromwel:
Then you cou'd cringe and sneere— and hold the Door;
And give him every Opportunity
Had not my Piety defeated your Endeavours.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: That was for Glory,
Who wou'd not be a Cuckold to be great?
— If Cromwel leap'd into my Saddle once,
I'll step into his Throne for't: but, to be pointed at
By Rascals that I— rule,— 'tis insupportable.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: How got this Fellow drunk; call up my Officers:
Who dur'st deliver him this Quantity of Wine?
Send straight in my Name, to summon all the
Drunken Committee of Safety to my Presence.
By Heav'n I'll show you Sir— yes they shall
See what a fine King they'r like to have
In Honest, Gadly, Sober, Wise Iack Lambert.
— Nay, I'll do't; d'ye think to take away my Honour thus?
I, who by my sole Politicks and Management,
Have set you up Villain of Villains, Sirrah.
— Away— summon 'em all. to Gilliflower.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Stay— be not so rash; who was beneath the Carpet?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: I will not answer thee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nor any living thing?

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: No Creature in the Room, thou silly Idiot, but Gilliflower and I,— at our Devotion, praying to Heav'n for your Success to morrow;— and am I thus rewarded! Weeps, Gill. weeps too.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Soul, I cannot bear the sight of Tears
From these dear charming Eyes.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: No matter Sir, the Committee shall right me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Upon my Knees I ask thy Pardon Dear; by all that's good, I wou'd have sworn I'd felt something stir beneath me, as I sat, which threw me over.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Only your Brains turn'd round with too much drinking and dancing, Exercises you are not us'd to:— Go sleep, and settle 'em; for I'll not daign to Bed with you to Night;— retire, as 'ere you hope to have my Aid in your Advancement to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I'm gone,— and once more, pardon my Mistake. bows, and goes out.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: — So, this fighting Fool, so worshipp'd by the Rabble, how meanly can a Woman make him sneeke; to Loveless.— the happy Night's our own.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Excellent Creature, how I do adore thee!

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: But you, perhaps, are satisfy'd already.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Never! shou'dst thou be kind to all Eternity. Thou hast one Vertue more, I pay thee Homage for; I heard from the Alcove how great a Mistress thou art in the dear Mystery of Jilting.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: That's the first Lesson Women learn in Conventicles; Religion teaches those Maxims to our Sex, by this!
sp.l: Kings are depos'd, and Commonwealths are rul'd;
By Jilting all the Universe is fool'd.

div.head: Scene I. Street.
div.stage: Enter Corporal, half drest; with Souldiers, Ioyner and Felt-maker.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: HA Rogues, the City-Boys are up in Arms; brave Boys, all for the King now!

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Have a Care what you say Sir; but as to the City's being in Mutiny, that makes well for us: we shall fall to our old Trade of plundering, something will fall to the Righteous, and there is Plunder enough.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: You plunder Sirrah, knock him down, and carry him into the Guard-room, and secure him. Two Souldiers seize him.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: They say, the Committee of Safety sat all Night at General Lambert's, about some great Affair— some rare Change Rogues!

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Yes, and to put off Sorrow, they say, were all right reverendly drunk too.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I suppose so, there is some heavenly matter in hand; there was Treason cry'd out at the General's last Night, and the Committee of no Safety all ran away.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: Or rather reel'd away.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: — The Ladies squeek'd, the Lords fled, and all the House was up in Arms.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Yea, and with Reason they say; for, the Pope in diguise was found under the Ladies Bed, and two huge Jesuits as big as the Tall Irish-man, with Blunderbusses; having, as 'tis said, a design to steal the Crown now in Custody of the General.—

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Good lack, is't possible?

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: Nay Sir, 'tis true, and is't not time we look'd about us?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: A Pox upon ye all, for lying Knaves:— secure 'em both on the Guard, till farther Order,— and let us in to th' City-boys: hay for Lumbard-street.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Ay hay for Lumbard-street; there's a Shop I have mark'd out for my own already.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.p: There's a handsom Citizens Wife, that I have an Eye upon, her Husband's a rich Banker, I'll take t'one with t'other.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: You are mistaken Sir, that plunder is reserv'd for us, if they begin to mutiny; That wicked City that is so weary of a Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.p: Yes, they'r afraid of the Monster they themselves have made.

div.stage: Enter Lov. and Free. in disguise.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hah, my Noble Collonel; what, in Disguise!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: We have made our Escapes,— and hope to see better times shortly; the Noble Scotch General is come Boys.

div.stage: Enter Captain of the Prentices, and a great Gang with him, arm'd with Staffs, Swords, &c.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Come my Lads, since you have made me Captain, I'll lead you bravely on! I'll dye in the Cause, or bring you off with Victory.

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.p: Here's a Club shall do some Execution; I'll beat out Hewson's t'other Eye; I scorn to take him on the blind Side.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: In the first Place, we must all sign a Petition to my Lord Mayor.—

sp.speaker: 2 Pren.
sp.p: Petitions, we'll have no Petitions Captain; we are for Club Law, Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Obey, or I leave you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Obey, Obey.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Look ye, we'll petition for an honest Free Parliament I say.

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.p: No Parliament, no Parliament, we have had too much of that Mischief already Captain.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No Parliament, no Parliament.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Farewel Gentlemen, I thought I might have been heard.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Death Sirs, you shall hear the Captain out.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We obey, we obey.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I say, an honest Free Parliament, not one pick'd and chosen by Faction; but such an one shall do our Bus'ness Lads, and bring in the Great Heroick.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, the Great Heroick, the Great Heroick!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A fine Youth, and shou'd be encourag'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Good— in the next place, the noble Scotch General is come, and we'll side with him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, all side with him.

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.p: Your Reason, Captain, for we have acted too much without Reason already.

sp.speaker: 2 Pren.
sp.p: Are we sure of him, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh, he'll doubtless declare for the King, Boyes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hay, Via la Roy, via la Monk.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Next, I hear there's a Proclamation coming out to dissolve the Committee of no Safety.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Good, good.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And I hope you are all brave enough to stand to your Loyal Principles with your Lives and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We'll dye for the Royal Interest.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: In the next place, there's another Proclamation come out.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.p: This Captain is a man of rare Intelligence; but for what Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why— to— hang us all, if we do not immediately depart to our respective Vocations, how like you that, my Lads?

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.p: Hum— hang'd! I'll e'n home again.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: And I too, I do not like this hanging.

sp.speaker: 3. Pr.
sp.p: A man looks but scurvily with his Neck awry.

sp.speaker: 4 Pr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, We'll home.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why now you shew what precious men you are— the King wou'd be finely hope up with such Rascals, that for fear of a little hanging wou'd desert his Cause; a Pox upon ye all, I here discharge ye—
sp.l: — take back your Coward Hands, and give me Hearts, flings 'em a Scroll.
I scorn to fight with such mean-spirited Rogues.
I did but try your boasted Courages.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A brave Boy.

sp.speaker: Lov. and Free.
sp.p: We'll dye with thee, Captain—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh, noble Captain, we recant—

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: We recant, dear Captain, wee'l dy, one and all.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: One and all, one and all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why so, there's some trusting to you now.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.p: But is there such a Proclamation, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There is; but anon, when the Crop-ear'd Sheriff begins to read it, let every man inlarge his Voice, and cry, No Proclamation, no Proclamation.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Brave noble Lads, hold still your Resolution,
And when your leisure hours will give ye leave,
Drink the King's Health, here's Gold for you to do so.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Take my Mite too, brave Lads. gives 'em Gold.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hay! Viva the brave Heroicks.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Hum, What have we here, a Street-Conventicle!— or a Mutiny? Yea verily, it is a Mutiny,— What meaneth this appearance in Hostile manner, in open Street, by Day-light?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hah! one of the sanctify'd Lay Elders, one of the Fiends of the Nation, that go about like roaring Lyons, seeking whom they may devour?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Who, Mr. Ananias the Padder.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Bear Witness Gentlemen all, he calls me an High-way Man; thou shalt be hang'd for Scandal on the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll prove what I say, Sirrah; do not you rob on the High-way i'th' Pulpit? Rob the Sisters, and preach it lawful for them to rob their Husbands; rob men even of their Consciences and Honesty; nay, rather than stand out, rob poor Wenches of Bodkins and Thimbles.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: I commit ye; here Souldiers, I charge ye in the Name of— of— marry I know not who, in my Name, and the good People of England, take 'em to safe Custody.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How, lay hold of honest Gentlemen! Noble Cavaliers, knock him down.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Knock him down, knock him down.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Hold worthy Youths; the Rascal has done me Service.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: pulling off his Hat to 'em all. Ye look like Citizens, what evil Spirit is entered in unto you, oh men of London! that ye have changed your Note, like Birds of evil Omen; that you go astray after new Lights, or rather, no Lights, and commit Whoredom with your Fathers Idols, even in the midst of the Holy City, which the Saints have prepared for the Elect, the Chosen ones.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hark ye, Sirrah, leave preaching, and fall to declaring for us, or thou art mortal.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Nay, I say nay, I will dye in my Calling— yea I will fall a Sacrifice to the Good Old Cause; abomination ye with a mighty hand, and will destroy, demolish, and confound your Idols, those heathenish Malignants whom you follow, even with Thunder and Lightening, even as a Field of Corn blasted by a strong Blast.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Knock him down.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Down with Dagon, down with him.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Ah Rogues, have I caught ye napping? They all surround him and his Red-Coats.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Whoop Cobler, Whoop Cobler.

div.stage: The Boys, Lov. and Free. Corp. and Sould. beat off Hewson and his Party. An. gets a Sword, and fights too.

div.head: SCENE changes to a Chamber.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: I've had no time to ask your Highness how you slept to night; but that's a needless Question.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: How mean you? do you suspect my Vertue? do you believe Loveless dares attempt any thing against my Honour? No Gilliflower, he acted all things so like a Gentleman, that every Moment takes my Heart more absolutely.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: My Lord departed highly satisfied.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: She is not worthy of Intrigues of Love, that cannot mannage a silly Husband as she pleases— but Gilliflower, you forget that this is Council day.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: No but I do not, Madam, some important Suitors wait already.

div.stage: Enter La. Des. and La. Fleetwood.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Your Servant, Madam, Desbro, thour't welcom—
Gilliflower, are all things ready in the Council Chamber?
We that are Great must sometimes stoop to Acts,
That have at least some shew of Charity;
We must redress the Grievance of our People.

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.p: She speaks as she were Queen, but I shall put a Spoke in her rising Wheel of Fortune, or my Lords Politicks fail him Scen. draws off, Table with Papers: Chairs round it.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Where are the Ladies of the Council?— how remiss they are in their Attendance on us?

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.l: Us! Heav'ns, I can scarce indure this Insolence!
— We will take care to mind 'em of their Duty—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: We, poor Creature! how simply Majesty becomes her? They all sitting down, Enter La. Cromwel angrily, and takes her Place; Lamb. uppermost.— Madam, as I take it, at our last sitting, our pleasure was that you shou'd sit no more.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: Your pleasure! Is that the General Voice? This is my Place in spight of thee, and all thy fawning Faction, and I shall keep it, when thou, perhaps, shalt be an humble Suppliant here at my Foot-stool.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: I smile at thee.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Do, and cringe; 'tis thy bu'sness to make thee Popular—
But 'tis not that,
Nor thy false Beauty that will serve thy Ends.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Rail on; declining Majesty may be excus'd,
Call in the Women that attend for redress of Grievances. Ex. Pag.
sp.stage: Enter Page with Women, and Loveless dress'd as a Woman.
sp.l: Gentlewomen, what's your Business with us?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Gentlewomen? some of us are Ladies.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Ladies, in good time; by what Authority, and from whom do you derive your Title of Ladies?

sp.speaker: La. Feet.
sp.p: Have a care how you usurp what's not you own?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How the Devil rebukes Sin? aside.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: From whom had you your Honours, Women?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: From our Husbands.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Husbands; who are they, and of what standing?

sp.speaker: 2 Lad.
sp.p: Of no long standing, I confess.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: That's a common Grievance indeed.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: And ought to be redress'd.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: And that shall be taken into consideration; write it down, Gilliflower, Who made your Husband a Knight, Woman?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oliver the first, an't please ye.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Of horrid Memory; write that down— who yours?

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.p: Richard the Fourth, an't like your Honour.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Of sottish Memory; Shall I write that down too?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Most remarkably.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: Heav'ns! Can I hear this Profanation of our Royal Family? aside.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: I wonder with what impudence Noll and Dick cou'd Knightifie your Husbands? for 'tis a Rule in Heraldry, that none can make a Knight but him that is one; 'Tis Sancha Pancha's Case in Don Quixot.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: How dare you question my Husband's Authority? rises in Anger.
Who nobly won his Honour in the Field,
Not like thy sneaking Lord, who gain'd his Title
From his Wife's gay Love-tricks,
Bartering her Honour for his Coronet.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Thou ly'st, my Husband earn'd it with his Sword, braver and juster than thy bold Usurper, who waded to his Glory, through a Sea of Royal Blood.—

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Sure Loveless has done good on her, and converted her.

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.p: Madam, I humbly beg you will be patient, You'll ruine all my Lord's Designes else.— Women, proceed to your Grievances, both publick and private.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I petition for a Pension, my Husband, deceas'd, was a constant active man, in all the late Rebellion, against the Man; he plunder'd my Lord Capel, he betray'd his dearest Friend Brown Bushel, who trusted his Life in his hands, and several others; plundering their Wives and Children even to their Smocks.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Most considerable Service, and ought to be consider'd.

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.p: And most remarkably, at the Tryal of the late Man, I spit in's Face, and betray'd the Earl of Holland to the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: In the King's Face, you mean— it shew'd your zeal for the Good Cause.

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.p: And 'twas my Husband that headed the Rabble, to pull down Gog and Magog, the Bishops, broke the Idols in the Windows, and turn'd the Churches into Stables and dens of Thieves; rob'd the Altar of the Cathedral of the twelve pieces of Plate call'd the twelve Apostles, turn'd eleven of 'em into Money, and kept Iudas for his own use at home.

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.p: On my word, most wisely perform'd, note it down—

sp.speaker: 3 La.
sp.p: And my Husband made Libels on the Man, from the first Troubles to this day, defam'd and profan'd the Woman and her Children, printed all the man's Letters to the Woman with Burlesque Marginal Notes, pull'd down the sumptuous Shrines in Churches, and with the golden and Popish Spoils adorn'd his own Houses and Chimney Pieces.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: We shall consider these great Services.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: To what a height is Impudence arriv'd? aside.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Proceed to private Grievances.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: An't please your Honours, my Husband prayes too much; which both hinders his private Bus'ness at home, and his Publick Services to the Commonwealth—

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: A double Grievance— set it down, Gilliflower.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And then he rails against the Whore of Babylon, and all my Neighbours think he call me Whore.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: A most unpardonable fault.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: We'll have that rectify'd, it will concern us.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then he never kisses me, but he sayes a long Grace, which is more mortifying than inviting.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: That is the fault of all the new Saints, which is the reason their Wives take a pious care, as much as in them lies, to send 'em to Heaven, by making 'em Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.p: A very charitable work, and ought to be encourag'd.

div.stage: Loveless gives in a Petition to Gilliflower.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: The humble Petition of the Lady Make-shift, reads,— Heav'ns! Madam, here is many thousand hands to't of the distressed Sex.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Read it.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: reads. Whereas there pass'd an Act Iune 24th against Fornication and Adultery, to the great detriment of most of the young Ladies, Gentlewomen, and Commonalty of England, and to the utter decay of many whole Families, especially when married to old men; your Petitioners most humbly beg your Honours will take this great Grievance into Mature Consideration and that the said Act may be repealed.
— a blessing on 'em, they shall have my hand too.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: We acknowledge, there are many Grievances in that Act: but there are many Conveniences too, for it ties up the Villanous Tongues of men from boasting our Favours.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: But as it layes a Scandal on Society— 'tis troublesom, Society being the very Life of a Republick— Peters the first, and Martin the Second.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But in a Free State, why shou'd not we be free?

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Why not? we stand for the Liberty and Property of our Sex, and will present it to the Committee of Safety.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Secondly, we desire the Heroicks, vulgarly call'd the Malignants, may not be look'd on as Monsters, for assuredly they are Men; and that it may not be charg'd to us as a Crime to keep 'em company, for they are honest men.

sp.speaker: 2 L.
sp.p: And some of 'em men that will stand to their Principles.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Is there no other honest men that will do as well?

sp.speaker: 3 La.
sp.p: Good men are scarce.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: They're all for Heroicks, sure 'tis the mode to love 'em— I cannot blame 'em. aside.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
And that when we go to Mornings and Evenings Lectures, to Tantlings or elsewhere, and either before or after visit a private Friend, it may
be actionable for the Wicked to scandalize us, by terming of it, abusing the Creature, when 'tis harmless recreating the Creature.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Reason, Reason.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nor that any Husband shou'd interupt his Wife, when at her private Devotion.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: I have been too late sensible of that Grievance.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: And Madam, I wou'd humbly pray a Patent for Scolding, to ease my Spleen.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: An please Your Highness, here's a Messenger arriv'd Post, with Letters from my Lord, the General. Ex. Pag.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Greater Affairs— oblige us to break up the Council. Rises, the Women retire. Enter Page with Messenger, or Letters.— What means this Haste? Opens, and reads 'em.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: Hah, bless my Eye-sight, she looks pale,— now red again, some Turn to his Confusion, Heav'n, I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: My Lord's undone! His Army has deserted him;
Left him denfenceless to the Enemies Pow'r.
Ah Coward Traytors! Where's that brutal Courage
That made ye so successful in your Villanies?
Has Hell that taught ye Valour, now abandon'd ye?
— How in an Instant are my Glories fall'n!

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— What, has your Highness any cause of Grief?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p: Call up your Courage Madam, do not let these things scoff you,— you may be yet a Queen: Remember what Lilly told you Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Damn Lilly, who with lying Prophesies, has rais'd me to the hopes of Majesty: a Legend of his Divels take him for't.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: Oh, have a Care of Cursing, Madam!

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Screech-Owl, away, thy Voice is ominous.
Oh I cou'd rave! but that it is not great;
— And silent Sorrow— has most Majesty.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Wons Madam, undone, undone; our honourable Committee is gone to th' Diel, and the damn'd loosey Rump is aud in aud; the muckle Diel set it i'solt, and his Dam drink most fort.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: The Committee dissolv'd, whose wise Work was that? it looks like Fleetwood's silly Politicks.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Mary, and yar Ladiship's i'th' Right, 'twas en the Work o'th' faud Loone, the Diel brest his Wem for't.

div.stage: Enter Hewson, Desbro, Whitlock, Duc. and Cob.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: So Brethren in Iniquity, we have spun a fine Thread, the Rump's all in all now; rules the Rost, and has sent for the General with Sissers and Rasor.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: With a Sisserara, you mean.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: None of your Terms in Law, good Brother.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Right, but gen ya have any Querks in Law, Mr. Lyer, that will save our Crags, 'twill be warth a Fee.

sp.speaker: Duck.
sp.p: We have plaid our Cards fair.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Is deny that; Wans Sirs ya plaid 'em faul; a Fule had the shooftling of 'em, and the Muckle Diel himself turn'd up Trump.

sp.speaker: Whit.
sp.p: We are lost Gentlemen, utterly lost; who the Devil wou'd have thought of a Desolution?

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Is there no Remedy?

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.p: Death, I'le to the Scotch General; turn but in time as many greater Rogues than I have done, and 'twill save my Stake yet.— Farewel Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Des.
sp.p: No Remedy?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Nene Sirs agen the Kings Evel; Bread Sirs, ya's ene gang tol yat Stall agen: Is en follow Duckingfield— Farewel Mr. Leyer.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: See the Vicissitudes of Humane Glory.
These Rascals, that but Yesterday petition'd me
With humble Adoration, now scarce pay
Common Civilities due to my Sex alone.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.p: How now Fool, what is't that makes ye look so pertly? Some mighty Business you have done, I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Verily Lady Mother, you are the strangest Body; a Man cannot please you.— Have I not finely circumvented Lambert? Made the Rump Head, who have committed him to th' Tower; ne're stir now that I have, and I'm the greatest Man in England, as I live I am, as a Man may say.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: Yes, till a greater come. Ah Fool of Fools, not to fore-see the Danger of that nasty Rump.

sp.speaker: La. Fleet.
sp.p: Good Madam, treat my Lord with more Respect.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.l: Away fond Fool, born with so little Sense,
To doat on such a wretched Idiot;
It was thy Fate in Ireton's days, to love him,
Or you were foully scandall'd

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: You are not so well spoken of neither, ne're stir now, and you go to that. I can be King to morrow if I will.

sp.speaker: Crom.
sp.p: Thou ly'st, thou wo't be hang'd first; mark that I tell thee so. I'll prove Cassandra to thee, and prophesie thy Doom; Heav'n pays the Traytor back with equal measure. Remember how you serv'd my poor Son Richard. Ex. Crom. and Page

sp.speaker: Flee.
sp.p: She's mad— Come, my Dear, let's leave the House of this Villain that meant to have couzen'd me illegally of three Kingdoms,— but that I out-witted him at last. Ex. Fleet. La. Fleet. and Pag.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Imprison'd too, i'th' Tower! What Fate is mine? leans on Des.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Madam, the fine Heroick's come to wait on you.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Hah, Loveless! let him not see the Ruines of my Greatness, which he foretold, and kindly begg'd I wou'd usurp no more. weep.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This News has brought me back, I love this Woman! Vain as she is, in spight of all her Fopperies of State— bows to her, and looks sad.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Alas, I do not merit thy Respect,
I'm fall'n to Scorn, to Pity and Contempt. weeping.
Ah Loveless, fly the Wretched—
Thy Vertue is too noble to be shin'd on
By any thing but rising Suns alone:
I'm a declining shade.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: By Heaven, you were never great till now!
I never thought thee so much worth my Love,
My Knee, and Adoration, till this Minute. kneels.
— I come to offer you my Life, and all,
The little Fortune the rude Heard has left me.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Is there such god-like Vertue in your Sex?
Or rather, in your Party.
Curse on the Lies and Cheats of Conventicles,
That taught me first to think Heroicks Divels,
Blood-thirsty, lewd, tyrannick Salvage Monsters.
— But I believe 'em Angels all, if all like Loveless.
What heavenly thing then must the Master be,
Whose Servants are Divine?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Oh Madam! all the Heroick-Boys are up in Arms, and swear they'll have your Highness, dead or alive,— they have besieg'd the House.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Heavens, the Rabble!— those faithless things that us'd to crowd my Coaches Wheels, and stop my Passage, with their officious Noise and Adoration.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Loveless, Thy Aid; the City-Sparks are up;
Their zealous Loyalty admits no Bounds.
A glorious Change is coming, and I'll appear now bare fac'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Madam, fear not the Rabble; retire, Freeman and I can still 'em.

div.stage: leads her in, and bows low.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: My dear Maria, I shall claim ye shortly—

sp.speaker: L. D.
sp.l: Do your worst, I'm ready for the Challenge go in.

div.stage: Ex. Lov. and Free. another way.

div.head: SCENE. The Street.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I say we'll have the She-Polititian out, she did more mischief than her Husband, pittiful, dittiful Lambert; who is, thanks be praised, in the Tower, to which place, Lord of his mercy bring all the Kings Enemies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why how now Captain, what besiege the Women? No, let us lead our Force to Nobler Enemies.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay, noble Chief, your word's our Law.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, I resign that Title to the brave Scotch General, who has just now enter'd the City.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: We know it, Sir; Do you not observe how the Crop-ear'd Phanaticks trot out of Town?— The Rogues began their old belov'd Mutiny, but 'twou'd not do.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Pox upon 'em, they went out like the Snuff of a Candle, stinkingly and blinkingly.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let 'em hang themselves, and then they are cold meat for the Devil.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But noble Champion, I hope we may have leave to rost the Rump to Night?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: With all our hearts; here's Money to make Fires—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And here's for drink too't, Boyes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Hey— Via le Roy, via les Heroicks! go out hollowing.

div.stage: Enter Ananias peeping, Felt. and Ioyner.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: So, the Rabble's gone: ah, Brethren! what will this wicked World come too?

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Alack, alack, to no goodness, you may be sure; pray what's the News? Fleet peeping out of a Garret Window.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Anania, Anania.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Who calleth Ananias? lo, here am I.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: Behold, it is I, look up. How goeth tidings?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Full ill, I fear, 'tis a bad Omen to see your Lordship so nigh Heaven; when the Saints are Garettifi'd.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.p: I am fortifying my self against the Evil day.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Which is come upon us like a Thief in the Night; like a Torrent from the Mountain of Waters; or a Whirl-wind from the Wilderness.

sp.speaker: Flee.
sp.p: Why, what has the Scotch General done?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Ah! He playeth the Devil with the Saints in the City, because they put the Covenant Oath unto him, he pulls up their Gates, their Posts and Chains, and enters.

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: And wou'd the wicked City let him have his beastly will of her?

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: Nay, but she was ravished— deflow'red.

sp.speaker: Ioyn.
sp.p: How, ravish'd! oh, monstrous! was ever such a Rape committed upon an innocent City? lay her Legs open to the wide World, for every Knave to view her Nakedness?

sp.speaker: Felt.
sp.p: Ah, ah! what Dayes, what Times, and what Seasons are here?

div.stage: Enter Capt. Corporal, and Prentices, with faggots, hollowing.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: What say you now, Lads, is not my Prophesie truer than Lillie's? I told you the Rump wou'd fall to our handling, and drinking for: the Kingss proclaim'd, Rogues.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Lilly, a Plague on him, he prophesied Lambert shou'd be uppermost.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Yes, he meant perhaps on Westminster Pinacle; where's Lilly now, with all his Prophecies against the Royal Family?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: In one of his Twelve Houses.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: We'll fire him out to night, Boy; come, all hands to work for the Fire. Exeunt all, hollowing.

sp.speaker: Fleet.
sp.l: Ah, dismal, heavy day, a day of Grief and Wo,
Which hast bereft me of my hopes for ay, ah Lard, what shall I do? Exit.

div.head: SCENE. A Chamber.
div.stage: Enter Lov. leading La. Lam. in disguise, Page and Gilliflower disguis'd, Lov. dressing her.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: My Charmer, why these Tears?
If for the fall of all thy painted Glories,
Thou art, in the esteem of all good men,
Above what thou wer't then:
The glorious Sun is rising in our Hemisphere,
And I, amongst the crowd of Loyal Sufferers,
Shall share in its kindly Rayes.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Best of thy Sex—
What have I left to gratifie thy goodness?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You have already by your noble Bounty
Made me a Fortune, had I nothing else;
All which I render back, with all that Wealth
Heaven and my Parents left me:
Which, tho' unjustly now detain'd from me,
Will once again be mine, and then be yours.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Come, haste, the Rabble gather round the House,
And swear they'll have this Sorceress.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Let me loose among 'em, their rude officious honesty must be punish'd.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.l: Oh, let me out, do not expose thy Person to their mad rage, rather resign the Victim. holds him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Resign thee! By Heaven, I think I shou'd turn Rebell first.

div.stage: Enter La. Des. disguis'd, and Page, with Iewels in a Box.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: With much ado, according to thy direction, dear Freeman, I have pass'd the Pikes, my House being surrounded, and my Husband demanded, fell down dead with fear.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How, thy Husband dead!

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: Dead as old Oliver! and much ado I got off with these Jewels, the Rabble swore I was one of the Party, and had not the honest Corporal convinc'd 'em, I had been pull'd to pieces:— Come, haste away, Madam, we shall be rosted with the Rump else.

sp.speaker: La. Lam.
sp.p: Adieu, dear Mansion! whose rich gilded Roofs so oft put me in mind of Majesty— And thou my Bed of State, where my soft Slumbers have presented me with Diadems and Scepters,— when waking I have stretch'd my greedy Arms to grasp the vanish'd Phantom! ah, adieu! And all my hopes of Royalty adieu.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And dare you put your self into my Protection? Well, if you do, I doubt you'll never be your own Woman again.

sp.speaker: La. Des.
sp.p: No matter, I'm better lost than found on such occasions. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE, a Street; a great Bonfire, with Spits, and Rump rosting, and the Mobile about the Fire, with Pots, Bottles, and Fiddles.

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.p: Here, Iack, a Health to the King.

sp.speaker: 2 Pren.
sp.p: Let it pass, Lad, and next to the Noble General.

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.p: Ralph, baste the Rump well, or ne'r hope to see a King agen.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.p: The Rump will baste it self, it has been well cram'd.

div.stage: Enter Freeman, La. Des. Loveless, and La. Lam. Gill. Pages, &c.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hah, Noble Champion, Faith Sir, you must honour us so far as to drink the King's Health, and the Noble General's before you go.

div.stage: Enter Wareston, drest like a Pedlar, with a Box about his Neck full of Ballads and things.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Will ya buy a Guedly Ballat or a Scotch Spur Sirs? a guedly Ballat or a Scotch Spur.— S'bread, Is scapt hither te weele enough, Is sav'd my Crag fro stretching twa Inches longer than 'twas borne: will ya buy a Jack line to rost the Rump, a new Iack Lambert line,— or a blithe Ditty, of the Noble Scotch General— come buy my Ditties.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How a Ditty o'th' General? let's see't, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: S'bread, Sirs, and here's the guedly Ballad of the General's coming out of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Here, who sings it? we'll all bear the bob.

div.stage: Wariston sings the Ballad, all bearing the Bob.

sp.speaker: Ana.
sp.p: New Almanacks, new Almanacks.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hah, who have we here? Ananias Holder-forth of Clements Parish?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, a Traytor, a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If I be not mistaken, this blithe Ballad-singer too was Chair-man to the Committee of Safety.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Is your Lordship turn'd Pedlar at last?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: What mon I do noo? Lerd, ne mere Lerd than yar sel Sir; wons Is show 'em a fair pair a heeles. goes to run away, they get him on a Colt-staff, with Ananias on another, Fidlers playing Fortune my Foe round the Fire.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Play Fortune my Foe, Sirrah.

div.stage: Enter Hewson, drest like a Country-Fellow.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Who are you, Sirra? you have the mark o'th' Beast.

sp.speaker: Hews.
sp.p: Who, aye, Sir? aye am a Doncer, that come a merry making among ya—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Come, Sirrah, your Feats of Activity quickly then.

div.stage: He dances, which ended, they get him on a colt-staff, and cry a Cobler, a Cobler.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Cobler, a Cobler.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To Prison with the Traytors, and then we have made a good Nights work on't.
sp.l: Then let's all home, and to the Powers Divine,
Pray for the King, and all the Sacred Line.

div.head: EPILOGUE spoken by Lady DESBRO.
div.l: THe Vizors off, and now I dare appear
High for the Royal Cause in Cavelier;
Though once as true a Whig as most of you,
Cou'd Cant, and Lye, Preach and dissemble too;
So far you drew me in, but faith I'le be
Reveng'd on you for thus debauching me,
Some of your pious Cheats I'le open lay,
That lead your Ignoramus Flock astray:
For since I cannot fight, I will not faile
To exercise my Tallent; that's to raile:
Yee Race of Hypocrites, whose Cloak of Zeal
Covers the Knave that cants for Common Weale,
All Laws the Church and State to ruine brings,
And impudently set a Rule on Kings
Ruine, destroy, all's good that you decree
By your Infallible Presbitery.
Prosperous at first, in ills you grow so vain,
You thought to Play the Old Game ore again,
And thus the cheat was put upon the Nation,
First with long Parliaments, next Reformation:
And now you hop'd to make a new invasion,
And when you can't prevaile by open force,
To cunning tickling tricks you have recourse,
And raise Sedition forth without remorse.
Confound these cursed Tories then they cry In a Preaching Tone.
Those Fools, those Pimps to Monarchy;
Those that Exclude the Saints; yet open th' Door
To introduce the Babylonian Whore:
By Sacred Oliver the Nations mad;
Beloved, 'twas not so when he was Head!
But then, as I have said it oft before yee,
A Cavelier was but a Type of Tory.
The Currs durst then not bark but all the Breed
Is much increas'd since that good Man was dead,
Yet then they rail'd against the Good Old Cause,
Rail'd foolishly for Loyalty and Laws;
But when the Saints had put them to a stand,
We left them Loyalty and took their Land:
Yea, and the Pious work of Reformation
Rewarded was with Plunder, Sequestration;
Thus can't the faithfull, nay, they'r so uncivill
To pray us harmless Players to the Devil,
When this is all th' Exception they can make,
They damn us for our glorious Masters sake.
But why gainst us do you unjustly erm
Our small Religion sure can do no harm,
Or if it do, since thats the only thing
We will reform, when you are true to th' King.
